A '''feud letter''' ({{lang-de|Fehdebrief}} or ''Absagebrief'') was a [[document]] in which a [[feud]] was announced – usually with few words - in medieval Europe. The letter had to be issued three days in advance in order to be legally valid. So that the feud did not became a case of [[murder]] and thus become punishable by law, those involved had to abide by the following rules: # The feud, whether between [[knight]]s or between the [[nobility]] and towns, had to be initiated by a formal feud letter # The killing of innocent parties was forbidden # The razing of houses and laying waste to the land was allowed # During the feud, fighting was not permitted in churches or in the home, and the parties were to be allowed go to and return from church or court without being molested. == Examples == * Around 1444, the town of [[Soest, Germany|Soest]] declared war on the [[Archbishop]] of [[Cologne]] at the start of the [[Soest Feud]] with the following famous, brief feud letter: ''"Wettet, biscop Dierich van Moeres, dat wy den vesten Junker Johan can Cleve lever hebbet alls Juwe, unde wert Juwe hiermit affgesaget"''
(''"Know this, Bishop Dietrich of Moers, that we prefer the steadfast [[Junker]], John of Cleves, to you, and hereby give you notice thereof."'') ==See also== *[[Throw down the gauntlet]] *''[[Landfrieden]]'' - waiver of the right to feuding [[Category:Legal documents]] [[Category:Feuds|Letter]] {{hist-stub}}

{{good article}} {{Infobox Politician | name = Gary Schiff | residence = [[Corcoran, Minneapolis]] | image = Gary Schiff launches his campaign for Minneapolis Mayor 8426916171 o.jpg | imagesize = 250px | caption = Schiff announcing his candidacy for Minneapolis mayor in 2013 | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1972|02|3|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Youngstown, New York]] | birth_name = Gary J. Schiffhauer | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | known = | alma_mater = [[University of Minnesota]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]]) | office1 = Member of the [[Minneapolis City Council]] from the 9th Ward | term_start1 = December 17, 2001 | term_end1 = January 6, 2014 | predecessor1 = Kathy Thurber | successor1 = Alondra Cano | constituency1 = | occupation = Activist | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = [[Minnesota Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party|Democratic-Farmer-Labor]] | religion = | spouse = | children = | relations = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Gary Schiff''' (born February 3, 1972, as '''Gary J. Schiffhauer''') is an American politician and activist who represented Ward 9 on the [[Minneapolis City Council]]. A member of the [[Minnesota Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party]] (DFL), he was first elected in 2001 and re-elected in 2005 and 2009. Prior to his political career, Schiff was involved with a variety of activist groups and causes ranging from human rights with the [[Human Rights Campaign]], to historic preservation with Save Our [[Cowles Center for Dance and the Performing Arts|Shubert]].
During his city council tenure, Schiff worked to ease ordinances prohibitive to small businesses, especially [[microbreweries]], and strongly advocated against a publicly funded [[U.S. Bank Stadium|stadium]] for the [[Minnesota Vikings]]. In January 2013, Schiff began a campaign for mayor of Minneapolis in the [[2013 Minneapolis mayoral election|2013 election]] but after an unsuccessful DFL endorsement convention, dropped out of the race and backed an opponent (the eventual winner) in mid-June. His third and final term on the City Council ended in January 2014.
Schiff took over as president of the Council on Crime and Justice the following July. A federal audit identified misused grant funds under Schiff's leadership. The organization closed abruptly following his termination. <ref name="cano challengers">{{cite news|last1=Belz|first1=Adam|title=In race for Minneapolis' Ninth Ward, Council Member Alondra Cano draws two well-known challengers|url=http://www.startribune.com/in-race-for-minneapolis-ninth-ward-council-member-alondra-cano-draws-two-well-known-challengers/416520143/|accessdate=April 2, 2017|work=[[Star Tribune]]|date=March 18, 2017}}</ref><ref name="ccj closes">{{cite news|last1=Stahl|first1=Brandon|title=Council on Crime and Justice abruptly shuts down|url=http://www.startribune.com/council-on-crime-and-justice-abruptly-shuts-down/380287091/|accessdate=April 2, 2017|work=[[Star Tribune]]|date=May 20, 2016}}</ref> In January 2017, he announced his candidacy for Minneapolis's 9th Ward City Council seat in the 2017 municipal elections.
==Early life== Schiff was born Gary J. Schiffhauer<ref>{{cite news|last=Hudkins|first=Lonnie|title=Reporters' Notebook|newspaper=The Buffalo News|date=March 29, 1989}}</ref> on February 3, 1972,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Schiff|first1=Gary|title=Join Mark Dayton for Gary Schiff's 40th Birthday Breakfast!|url=https://www.facebook.com/events/141689589284344/|website=Facebook|accessdate=February 3, 2015|date=February 3, 2012}}</ref> and grew up the youngest of six children in Western New York State.<ref name=notonfence>{{cite news|last=Roper|first=Eric|title=Minneapolis City Council's Schiff: 'Not one to sit on a fence'|url=http://www.startribune.com/local/minneapolis/159508905.html|accessdate=March 17, 2013|newspaper=Star Tribune|date=June 19, 2012}}</ref> In 1990, the [[American Civil Liberties Union]] represented Schiff after he graduated from [[Lewiston-Porter Central School District#High school|Lewiston-Porter High School]] in his hometown of [[Youngstown, New York]]. According to ''[[The Buffalo News]]'', Schiff had painted a mural along the school's stairwell that referenced "drugs, safe sex, AIDS and racism" in the style of artist [[Keith Haring]].<ref name=mural>{{cite news|last=Graves|first=Neil|title=Forum Airs Issues in Mural Flap: Ultimate Resolution May Rest With Court|newspaper=Buffalo News|date=September 14, 1990}}</ref> In September of that year, the school's superintendent, Walter S. Polka, decided that parts of the mural's text were objectionable.<ref name=mural/> The American Civil Liberties Union became involved in an extended legal fight over the constitutionality of Polka's censorship, and a New York Supreme Court Justice sided with the Lewiston-Porter School Board.<ref>{{cite news|last=Baldwin|first=Richard E.|title=Costs in Mural Dispute Total $24,664: School Board Gets Report on Lew-Port's Legal Fees|newspaper=Buffalo News|date=July 17, 1991}}</ref> In 1991, the school board voted 5-1 to paint over the mural. The board cited Schiff's involvement in a recent [[ACT-UP]] demonstration at the school—where demonstrators gave condoms and safe sex literature to students—as a major influence on their decision.<ref>{{cite news|last=Chrzanowski|first=Ed|title=Lew-Port Board Votes to Paint Out Disputed Mural: Artist's Participation in ACT-UP is Factor|newspaper=Buffalo News|date=July 17, 1991}}</ref>
As part of a transition that included moving from Youngstown to [[Minneapolis]] to attend college at the [[University of Minnesota]], Schiff shortened his name from the original Schiffhauer as a result of his parents' shame and refusal to acknowledge his sexuality in the small conservative town of Youngstown NY where the family attended church in a conservative Roman Catholic Parish (St. Bernard's, Youngstown, NY). However, Robert and Rita Schiffhauer, Gary's parents, soon joined the PFLAG Chapter in nearby Buffalo, NY in order to understand and support their son which they continued to do throughout their lives. Schiff's official public statement is that he shortened his name in an effort to move athe memories of bullying that he said made his youth "an act of survival".<ref name=notonfence /> In October 1992, he and six other students protested against the [[Reserve Officers' Training Corps]] (ROTC) and its compliance with a longstanding ban on homosexuals in the military. The seven protesters interrupted a meeting of the University Board of Regents, demanded the expulsion of the ROTC from campus, and handcuffed themselves to the Regents' chairs. Wearing signs that read "$old," suggesting that their human rights had been traded for Federal grant money, Schiff and the six other students were arrested by University Police and each charged with misdemeanors.<ref>{{cite news|last=Pinney|first=Gregor W.|title=Seven Students Arrested Protesting ROTC Policy at 'U' Regents Meeting|newspaper=Star Tribune|date=October 10, 1992}}</ref>
From 1993 to 1995, Schiff directed the Progressive Student Leadership Exchange (PLSE), a program modeled on the [[Civil Rights Movement]]'s [[Freedom Summer]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Vaid|first=Urvashi|title=Virtual Equality: The Mainstreaming of Gay and Lesbian Liberation|year=1993|publisher=Anchor Books|location=New York|isbn=0385472994|pages=399–400}}</ref> The [[Human Rights Campaign]] (HRC) took interest in the program, and invited Schiff to direct it as the newly named "Youth College for Campaign Training" in Washington, D.C.<ref>{{cite web|title=HRC Launches First Youth College for Campaign Training|url=https://groups.google.com/group/bit.listserv.gaynet/tree/browse_frm/month/1996-03/b65654372545add4?rnum=101&_done=/group/bit.listserv.gaynet/browse_frm/month/1996-03?&pli=1|publisher=Human Rights Campaign|date=February 29, 1996|accessdate=November 12, 2012}}</ref> The HRC-funded program invited people aged 18–24 to participate in workshops, and sent the participants to "target states" where they worked in groups as campaign staff members. The program was still in operation as late as 2006.<ref>{{cite web|last=Corner|first=Matt|title=HRC Youth College for Campaign Training; Applications Accepted|url=http://interstateq.com/archives/696/|publisher=Interstate Q |date= March 8, 2006|accessdate=November 12, 2012}}</ref>
After graduating in 1994 with a [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]] in [[women's studies]],<ref name=mdmayorannouncement>{{cite news|url=http://www.mndaily.com/2013/01/29/schiff-joins-race-minneapolis-mayor|newspaper=Minnesota Daily|title=Schiff joins race for Minneapolis mayor|date=January 29, 2013|accessdate=January 29, 2013|first=Brian|last=Arola}}</ref><ref name=stribmayorannouncement>{{cite news|last=Roper|first=Eric|title=Schiff officially announces bid for mayor|url=http://www.startribune.com/local/blogs/188896401.html|accessdate=March 23, 2013|newspaper=Star Tribune|date=January 29, 2013}}</ref> Schiff moved to [[Washington, D.C.]] to work with the [[Human Rights Campaign]].<ref name=notonfence /> He returned to Minneapolis to work with Progressive Minnesota, "a grassroots group focused on community organizing and electoral politics."<ref>{{cite web|title=Frequently Asked Questions: When, and why, was TakeAction Minnesota formed?|url=http://www.takeactionminnesota.org/frequently_asked_questions/44|publisher=Take Action Minnesota|accessdate=June 24, 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120120043450/http://www.takeactionminnesota.org/frequently_asked_questions/44|archivedate=January 20, 2012}}</ref> In December 1997, he became involved in a fight to save the Shubert Theater, a former vaudeville house on "[[Block E (Minneapolis)|Block E]]" in downtown Minneapolis, after the Minneapolis City Council approved a redevelopment plan that called for the theater's demolition.<ref>{{cite news|last=Mack|first=Linda|title=The Shubert's Next Act: A Stroll Down Hennepin?|newspaper= Star Tribune|date=December 19, 1997|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-62621133.html}}</ref> Within days, Schiff organized "Save Our Shubert," a grassroots effort to preserve the theater.<ref>{{cite news|last=Peck|first=Claude|title=Moving the Shubert Seen as Possible but Pricey|newspaper= Star Tribune|date=December 19, 1997|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-62621198.html}}</ref> After eight months, during which time Save our Shubert acted as a media contact, lobbied the city council, and "kept the Shubert in the public eye",<ref name=preservationist>{{cite news|last=Roscoe|first=Robert|title=Interview With SOS Director Gary Schiff|url=http://www.mnpreservation.org/pdf/MNPreservationist%20Archives/1998/PAM2_1998.Vol_1.N_04.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131202233523/http://www.mnpreservation.org/pdf/MNPreservationist%20Archives/1998/PAM2_1998.Vol_1.N_04.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2013-12-02|accessdate=23 March 2013|newspaper=The Minnesota Preservationist|pages=12–13|format=PDF|date=September–October 1998}}</ref> the Minneapolis City Council voted 9-3 to move the theater to a space adjacent to the [[Hennepin Center for the Arts]] at a cost of $3.9 million.<ref>{{cite news|last=Brandt|first=Steve|title=Shubert to take its show on the road|newspaper= Star Tribune|date=August 22, 1998|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-62564897.html}}</ref>
==Minneapolis City Council==
Schiff, at the time working as a [[teaching assistant]] in the University of Minnesota's [[Hubert H. Humphrey School of Public Affairs]]<ref name=mdmayorannouncement /> on his way to earning a [[master's degree]] in [[urban planning]],<ref name=preservationist /> took a leave of absence to run for a seat on the Minneapolis City Council against Michael Guest and Kathy Thurber in 2001.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Olson|first1=Rochelle|title=Thurber Won't Seek Reelection to Minneapolis City Council|newspaper= Star Tribune|date=February 9, 2001|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-70200750.html}}</ref> He won unanimous DFL endorsement on September 11, 2001 and, in a race that was overshadowed by the [[2001 terrorist attacks]], he ran against Lucky Rosenbloom, an African-American Republican.<ref name=stribed2001>{{cite news|last=''Star Tribune'' editorial staff|title=Minneapolis City Council|newspaper= Star Tribune|date=October 21, 2001}}</ref> Schiff received the endorsement of the ''[[Star Tribune]]'', which noted his "first-hand knowledge" of [[light rail]] systems in other U.S. cities.<ref name=stribed2001/> Elected by a large majority in November 2001, Schiff became one of seven newly elected members on the 13-member city council, joining two [[Green Party of Minnesota|Green Party]] members, two other openly gay council members, one African-American council member, and four women.<ref>{{cite news|last=Brunswick|first=Mark|title=Minneapolis City Council|newspaper= Star Tribune|date=November 7, 2001}}</ref> He was sworn into office on December 17, 2001, earlier than his fellow councilmembers, when Thurber resigned from her seat to assume the position of deputy director of [[Perpich Center for Arts Education]].<ref>{{cite news|title=New face on the City Council|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/openurl?ctx_ver=z39.88-2004&rft_id=info:sid/iw.newsbank.com:AWNB:STMB&rft_val_format=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:ctx&rft_dat=0F07F91B63A0FAC7&svc_dat=InfoWeb:aggregated5&req_dat=0FEAA90C14DCEF00|accessdate=January 9, 2014|newspaper=Star Tribune|date=December 18, 2001}}{{subscription required|via=NewsBank}}</ref>
===First term (2001–05)===
In his first term, Schiff sponsored and cosponsored numerous legal reforms to the Minneapolis Zoning Code that reduced bureaucratic obstacles for small businesses and housing developers, including a measure that permitted sidewalk cafes to use permanent outdoor furniture<ref>{{cite news|last=Nelson|first=Rick|title=Proposal Would Prettify City's Sidewalk Cafes|newspaper= Star Tribune|date=June 28, 2002|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-87934703.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Keefe|first=Merry|title=Regular Meeting of August 9, 2002|url=http://www.minneapolismn.gov/www/groups/public/@council/documents/proceedings/wcms1q-069959.pdf|work=Minneapolis City Council Official Proceedings|publisher=City of Minneapolis|accessdate=March 24, 2013|pages=683–684|format=PDF|date=November 5, 2002}}</ref> and a change in city zoning code that facilitated the construction of denser and more affordable housing.<ref>{{cite news|title=Minneapolis City Council: Bonuses to Boost Housing Approved, Higher Density, More Low-Cost Units Sought|newspaper= Star Tribune|date=November 23, 2002|first1=Kevin |last1=Duchscher|first2=Rochelle|last2= Olson}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Keefe|first=Merry|title=Regular Meeting of November 22, 2002|url=http://www.minneapolismn.gov/www/groups/public/@council/documents/proceedings/wcms1q-069967.pdf|work=Minneapolis City Council Official Proceedings|publisher=City of Minneapolis|accessdate=March 24, 2013|pages=1153–1157|format=PDF|date=April 28, 2003}}</ref> He also sponsored an ordinance to add domestic partnerships to the Zoning Code's definition of "family" in terms of housing.<ref>{{cite web|last=Ristuben|first=Steven J.|title=Regular Meeting of December 13, 2002|url=http://www.minneapolismn.gov/www/groups/public/@council/documents/proceedings/wcms1q-069970.pdf|work=Minneapolis City Council Official Proceedings|publisher=City of Minneapolis|accessdate=March 23, 2013|pages=1204–1205|format=PDF|date=January 30, 2003}}</ref>
In 2003, with colleagues Barbara Johnson and Sandy Colvin Roy, Schiff developed a last-minute plan to restore $2 million in proposed cuts to the Minneapolis [[Minneapolis Fire Department|Fire]] and [[Minneapolis Police Department|Police]] Departments, following a $26 million cut from Local Government Aid by former Governor [[Tim Pawlenty]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Olson|first1=Rochelle|title=Some Fire, Police Jobs Spared: In Adjusting and Approving Budget Cuts, the Minneapolis City Council Finds a Way to Save Positions|newspaper= Star Tribune|date=March 4, 2003|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-98778769.html}}</ref> That same year, he sponsored an ordinance that effectively blocked police officers, city inspectors, and other city employees from inquiring about a resident's immigration status. The ordinance forbids police officers from arresting a suspect solely on the grounds of a suspected immigration status violation.<ref>{{cite news|last=Brandt|first=Steve|title=Minneapolis OKs Rule on Immigrants: City Employees are Now Limited in What They Can Do to Turn People in for Possible Immigration Violations|newspaper= Star Tribune|date=July 12, 2003|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-105642078.html}}</ref>
===Second term (2005–09)===
In July 2004, the Minneapolis City Council passed a ban on indoor smoking in bars, restaurants, pool halls, and bowling alleys by a 12-1 margin.<ref>{{cite news|last=Scheck|first=Tom|title=Minneapolis City Council Passes Smoking Ban|publisher=Minnesota Public Radio|url=http://news.minnesota.publicradio.org/features/2004/07/23_scheckt_mplssmokeban/|date=July 23, 2004}}</ref> In March 2005, the ban took effect alongside other indoor smoking bans passed by other cities in the [[Minneapolis-St. Paul metropolitan area]].<ref name=Stellar>{{cite news|last=Stellar|first=Chris|title=Ward Nine: Schiff, Bicking Vie Again|newspaper=Minnesota Independent|date=September 7, 2009|url=http://minnesotaindependent.com/43772/ward-nine-schiff-bicking-eberhardy|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111218235042/http://minnesotaindependent.com/43772/ward-nine-schiff-bicking-eberhardy|archivedate=December 18, 2011}}</ref> Subsequently, during the [[Minneapolis municipal elections, 2005|2005 Minneapolis City Council elections]], a write-in candidate named Dave Shegstad received 10 percent of the ninth ward vote under a "Smoke Out Gary" campaign slogan—a reference to Schiff's role as a co-author of the smoking ban. 59 percent of voters re-elected Schiff to a second term; his main opponent, Green Party candidate David Bicking, won 30 percent of the vote.<ref name=Stellar/>
In 2006, Schiff sponsored eliminating a cap on taxi licenses in Minneapolis. The move angered some local taxi drivers, who noted that an attending increase in licenses would lead to greater competition in the local taxicab business.<ref>{{cite news|last=Giles|first=Kevin|title=Hailing, Howling Follow New Cab Rules: Everyone Agrees that Minneapolis' New Taxi Ordinance Will Mean Changes|newspaper= Star Tribune|date=October 10, 2006|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-152597171.html}}</ref> The City Council passed the cap lift, and the number of Minneapolis taxis doubled between 2010 and 2012.<ref>{{cite news|last=Roper|first=Eric|title=A Bumper-to-Bumper Crop of Cabs|newspaper= Star Tribune|date=May 9, 2012|url=http://www.startribune.com/local/minneapolis/150704145.html}}</ref>
Beginning in 2008, Schiff and other city leaders contended with local ramifications of the [[2008-2012 global recession]], which included spate of foreclosures in economically distressed neighborhoods. In April 2008, the city council approved a pilot mortgage assistance program called Minneapolis Advantage. The program, which passed the council 10-2, offered [[forgivable loan]]s to homebuyers who were interested in properties on the same block as foreclosed or city-owned properties within targeted neighborhoods.<ref name=Brandt>{{cite news|last=Brandt|first=Steve|title=Minneapolis City Council authorized a pilot loan program Friday to try to prop up foreclosure-sapped neighborhoods|newspaper= Star Tribune|date=April 5, 2008|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-177693282.html}}</ref> Schiff argued that the initiative was not targeted enough to have the designed effect and voted against it, along with fellow councilmember Paul Ostrow.<ref name=Brandt/>
The city also strictly regulated non-motorized [[pedicab]]s; it first permitted the bicycle-powered taxis in 1984, but there were no active pedicab licenses in the city by 2008.<ref name=Pease>{{cite news|last=Pease|first=Steve|title=Greasing the Wheels: Pedicab Hours Expanded|newspaper=Downtown Journal|date=September 8, 2008|url=http://www.journalmpls.com/node/12265|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130411045113/http://www.journalmpls.com/node/12265|archivedate=April 11, 2013|df=}}</ref> Schiff proposed eliminating some restrictions, and the city council passed ordinances allowing pedicabs to operate on downtown streets, downtown bridges, and on the Nicollet Mall, at any time except the morning and evening rush hours.<ref name=Pease/> In October 2011, when the city permitted pedicabs to operate during rush hours (with new safety regulations), eight licensed pedicab companies operated forty cabs in the downtown area.<ref>{{cite news|last=Brandt|first=Steve|title=Keeping Tabs on Pedicabs|newspaper= Star Tribune|date=October 9, 2011|url=http://www.startribune.com/local/minneapolis/131431988.html}}</ref>
===Third term (2009–13)=== [[File:Gary Schiff 2009 Ward 9 Candidate Forum.png|thumb|left|Gary Schiff speaking at a Ward 9 candidate forum in 2009]] In February 2012, a reporter for the ''[[Minnesota Daily]]'' wrote that Schiff is "possibly the most active and popular City Council member" and noted that 60 percent of Ward 9 voters reelected him to a third term in 2009.<ref>{{cite news|last=Sudheimer|first=Nick|title=Map Would Pit Ward 2’s Cam Gordon against Fellow Councilman: The Green Party is Concerned About the Proposed Map|newspaper=Minnesota Daily|date=February 20, 2012|url=http://www.mndaily.com/2012/02/20/map-would-pit-ward-2%E2%80%99s-cam-gordon-against-fellow-councilman}}</ref>
An avid supporter of microbrewing in Minneapolis, Schiff sponsored the "Brew Beer Here" ordinance that allowed the sale of 64-ounce "[[Growler (jug)|growlers]]" of beer on Minneapolis brewery premises.<ref>{{cite news |last=Brandt |first=Steve |title=City Council Could Open Doors for Brewers: The Changed Ordinance Would Allow Microbrewers to Sell Products directly, Instead of Relying on Distributors |newspaper=Star Tribune |date=August 3, 2010 |url=http://www.startribune.com/local/minneapolis/99810369.html |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6E2F8w7x7?url=http://www.startribune.com/local/minneapolis/99810369.html |archivedate=January 29, 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Passed in August 2010, the ordinance facilitated brewery operation within Minneapolis city limits and led to the opening of Harriet Brewing Company, the first Minneapolis brewery to open in decades.<ref>{{cite news|last=Horgen|first=Tom|title=Brewing Comes Home: After a Change in the Law, Harriet Brewing is the First New Brewery in the City of Minneapolis in Almost a Decade|newspaper=Star Tribune|date=February 4, 2011|url=http://www.startribune.com/entertainment/dining/115103284.html|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120304024845/http://www.startribune.com/entertainment/dining/115103284.html|archivedate=March 4, 2012|df=}}</ref> With colleague Elizabeth Gidden, Schiff co-sponsored the "Surly Bill," an ordinance that permits breweries to sell pints of their products on-site.<ref>{{cite news|last=Brandt|first=Steve|title=Minneapolis Plan to Aid Fledgling Brewers Advances|newspaper= Star Tribune|date=August 8, 2011|url=http://www.startribune.com/local/minneapolis/127279918.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Rybak signs new 'taproom' beer ordinance|url=http://www.kare11.com/news/article/935626/14/Rybak-signs-new-taproom-beer-ordinance--,|publisher=KARE-11 News |date=August 24, 2011|accessdate=November 19, 2012}}</ref> Schiff also proposed eliminating zoning constraints against establishments serving alcohol within 300 feet of a house of worship outside of the downtown area.<ref>{{cite news|title=Church-Spirits Rules are Outdated, Unfair: Relaxing Minneapolis Ordinance Would Help Small Businesses|newspaper=Star Tribune|date=November 14, 2011|author=Editorial|url=http://www.startribune.com/opinion/editorials/133719673.html|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131202225006/http://www.startribune.com/opinion/editorials/133719673.html|archivedate=December 2, 2013|df=}}</ref> The ordinance change was inspired by a struggle between Rob Miller, a brewer interested in opening a "pico brewery" called Dangerous Man Brewing in Northeast Minneapolis,<ref>{{cite news|last=Agnew|first=Michael|title=It's boom time for breweries: It's a good time to be a beer lover in Minnesota|newspaper= Star Tribune|date=January 5, 2012|url=http://www.startribune.com/lifestyle/taste/136680478.html}}</ref> and the church of Saints Cyril and Methodius Church, located across the street from the brewery's proposed location.<ref>{{cite news|last=Roper|first=Eric|title=City Explores Easing Church-Spirits Separation|newspaper= Star Tribune|date=November 7, 2011|url=http://www.startribune.com/politics/statelocal/133335713.html}}</ref> Citing his work to ease ordinances prohibitive to the microbrewing industry, ''Twin Cities Business'' named Schiff the most business-friendly city councilor in Minneapolis in 2012.<ref>{{cite news|title=Government & Public Policy|url=http://tcbmag.com/Honors-and-Events/Minnesotans-You-Should-Know/The-Black-Book/Government-Public-Policy|accessdate=23 March 2013|newspaper=Twin Cities Business|date=November 21, 2012}}</ref>
In 1997, before he became a member of the city council, Schiff co-authored an amendment to the City of Minneapolis Charter that mandated a voter referendum on city stadium subsidies that cost taxpayers over $10 million.<ref>{{cite news|last=Roper|first=Eric|title=Anti-Vikings Stadium Crowd Silent|newspaper= Star Tribune|date=May 29, 2012|url=http://www.startribune.com/local/minneapolis/155191275.html}}</ref> As of 2009, the Minnesota Vikings were moving forward on a $870 million plan to rebuild a downtown stadium on the site of the [[Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome]].<ref>{{cite news|title=New Vikings Stadium Proposal: $870M, No Pay Plan,|url=http://www.thestreet.com/story/10648689/1/new-vikings-stadium-proposal-870m-no-pay-plan.html|accessdate=November 19, 2012|newspaper=The Street|date=December 12, 2009|author=Associated Press}}</ref> The team also considered building a new stadium in other cities, including [[Anoka, Minnesota]]<ref>{{cite news|last=Buchan|first=Cliff|title=Anoka County/Vikings’ Stadium Proposal Gone, not Forgotten|newspaper=Forest Lake Times|date=November 23, 2011}}</ref> and [[Los Angeles]], California.<ref>{{cite news |title=Vikings Stadium Movement Afoot; NFL Boss Arriving; Wilf's Plane Spotted in L.A. Area |newspaper=St. Paul Pioneer Press |date=April 19, 2012 |first=Doug |last=Belden |first2=Bill |last2=Salisbury |url=http://www.twincities.com/vikings/ci_20434290/senjem-now-expects-senate-panel-take-up-vikings |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6EEp1gINh?url=http://www.twincities.com/vikings/ci_20434290/senjem-now-expects-senate-panel-take-up-vikings |archivedate=February 6, 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Though supportive of the Vikings remaining in Minneapolis in 2012,<ref name=vikingsop>{{cite news|last=Schiff|first=Gary|title=Send Vikings Bill Back to the Legislature|newspaper= Star Tribune|date=May 22, 2012|url=http://www.startribune.com/opinion/commentaries/152703405.html}}</ref> Schiff became an outspoken critic of the financing plan for the [[U.S. Bank Stadium|stadium]] when it came to a vote before the Minneapolis City Council, in part because it bypassed the charter amendment.<ref name=Nelson/> Schiff also argued that the plan's estimated cost to Minneapolis taxpayers, cited at $150 million in construction costs, failed to account for interest, maintenance costs, and upgrades over the course of the stadium's expected 30-year lifespan.<ref name=vikingsop/> In a ''Star Tribune'' editorial, Schiff quoted figures presented by the city's chief financial officer, Kevin Carpenter, which estimated a cumulative, 30-year cost that could range from $675 million to $890 million.<ref>{{cite news|title=Minneapolis' Slice of Stadium Funding Could Jump|newspaper= Star Tribune|date=May 22, 2012|first=Eric|last= Roper|first2=Mike |last2=Kaszuba|url=http://www.startribune.com/politics/statelocal/149761315.html}}</ref> Despite Schiff's objections, the Minneapolis City Council approved the stadium financing 7-6.<ref>{{cite news|last=Melo|first=Frederick|title=Vikings Stadium Wins Minneapolis City Council's Final Approval|newspaper=St. Paul Pioneer Press|date=May 25, 2012|url=http://www.twincities.com/vikings/ci_20706554/vikings-stadium-minneapolis-city-council-has-one-last}}</ref> Subsequently, the football team moved forward with plans to demolish the Metrodome and rebuild a new stadium on the site, and Governor [[Mark Dayton]] signed a financing plan approved by the legislature.<ref name=Nelson>{{cite web|last=Nelson|first=Tim|title=Dayton's Signature Will Set Vikings Stadium Preparations in Motion|publisher=Minnesota Public Radio|date=May 14, 2012|url=http://minnesota.publicradio.org/display/web/2012/05/14/vikings-stadium-bill-signing}}</ref>
==Mayoral bid (2013)== [[File:Gary Schiff, 2013 DFL convention.jpg|thumb|right|Schiff addressing the ill-fated DFL endorsement convention on June 15, 2013]] Schiff had been considering running for mayor of Minneapolis in the [[2013 Minneapolis mayoral election]] as early as June 2012, and stated that his ultimate decision would not be contingent upon whether mayor [[R.T. Rybak]] opted to run for another term.<ref name=notonfence /> Speaking from the Harriet Brewing tap room on January 29, 2013, Schiff announced his official candidacy for the position.<ref name=stribmayorannouncement /> On the same day, he also held an event in the [[Dinkytown]] area near the University of Minnesota with rapper [[Brother Ali]] to kick off his campaign.<ref name=mdmayorannouncement /> Schiff was the second City Councilmember to announce his candidacy after [[Betsy Hodges]] of Ward 13,<ref name=stribmayorannouncement /> and Don Samuels of Ward 5 announced his candidacy later.<ref name=mdmayorannouncement />
The University of Minnesota's [[Hubert H. Humphrey School of Public Affairs]] hosted the first mayoral debate on March 27, with Schiff among the five declared candidates who were seeking the DFL nomination.<ref>{{cite news|last=Boros|first=Karen|title=First Minneapolis mayoral debate ranges from public safety to Vikings stadium|url=http://www.minnpost.com/two-cities/2013/03/first-minneapolis-mayoral-debate-ranges-public-safety-vikings-stadium|accessdate=June 16, 2013|newspaper=MinnPost|date=March 28, 2013}}</ref> A week later, on April 4, Schiff took part in the city's second mayoral debate, this time located at a [[Kingfield, Minneapolis|Kingfield]]-neighborhood church.<ref name=debate2>{{cite news|last=Halter|first=Nick|title=Garbage burning, upbringing hot topics in second mayoral debate|url=http://www.southwestjournal.com/news/2013-city-election/garbage-burning-upbringing-hot-topics-in-second-mayoral-debate|accessdate=June 16, 2013|newspaper=[[Southwest Journal]]|date=April 4, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130715045034/http://www.southwestjournal.com/news/2013-city-election/garbage-burning-upbringing-hot-topics-in-second-mayoral-debate|archivedate=July 15, 2013|df=}}</ref> During the proceedings, he pledged that he would abide by the DFL's endorsement, making him the sole candidate to vow so among the five candidates seeking the endorsement at the time.<ref name=debate2 /> Schiff also participated in the city's first mayoral debate dealing specifically with issues concerning Minneapolis's [[Somali American|Somali population]], an event that took place on May 31 and was hosted at a Somali restaurant on [[Lake Street (Minneapolis)|Lake Street]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Rao|first=Maya|title=Minneapolis mayoral candidates mix it up in bid to woo Somali votes|url=http://www.startribune.com/local/minneapolis/209763281.html?page=all&prepage=1&c=y#continue|accessdate=June 16, 2013|newspaper=Star Tribune|date=June 1, 2013}}</ref> Schiff received endorsements from the Minneapolis Firefighters Union,<ref>{{cite news|last=Willms|first=Jan|title=Gary Schiff throws his hat into Mayoral race in Minneapolis|url=http://www.longfellownokomismessenger.com/gary-schiff-throws-his-hat-into-mayoral-race-in-minneapolis/|accessdate=June 16, 2013|newspaper=Longfellow/Nokomis Messenger|date=February 27, 2013}}</ref> [[Minnesota House of Representatives|state representative]] [[Karen Clark]],<ref name=qanda>{{cite news|last=Boros|first=Karen|title=Minneapolis mayoral candidate Gary Schiff Q-A: 'Every neighborhood should make progress'|url=http://www.minnpost.com/politics-policy/2013/04/minneapolis-mayoral-candidate-gary-schiff-q-every-neighborhood-should-make-p|accessdate=June 16, 2013|newspaper=MinnPost|date=April 3, 2013}}</ref> and former Vikings punter [[Chris Kluwe]],<ref>{{cite news|last=Rao|first=Maya|title=Former Viking Chris Kluwe endorses Schiff for mayor|url=http://www.startribune.com/local/blogs/209569301.html|accessdate=June 16, 2013|newspaper=Star Tribune|date=May 30, 2013}}</ref> among others.<ref name=qanda />
At the DFL endorsement convention, Schiff came in third place behind [[Mark Andrew (politician)|Mark Andrew]] and Hodges during the first two rounds of voting but was denied a place on the third round ballot after failing to meet a minimum vote threshold during round two.<ref name=wideopen>{{cite news|last=Rao|first=Maya|title=Mpls. mayoral race wide open after no one wins DFL endorsement|url=http://www.startribune.com/politics/statelocal/211698671.html?page=all&prepage=1&c=y#continue|accessdate=June 16, 2013|newspaper=Star Tribune|date=June 15, 2013|first2=Eric|last2=Roper}}</ref> When Schiff backed Hodges with the intention, according to the ''Star Tribune'', of preventing Andrew from receiving the 60% of votes needed to win the endorsement, he lost the support of the Minneapolis Firefighters Union.<ref name=wideopen /> The convention concluded with no winner and, because no one was endorsed, Schiff stated that he would remain in the race.<ref name=wideopen /> His campaign manager, Mark Warren, left Schiff's campaign shortly after the convention<ref name="loses campaign manager">{{cite news|last=Mannix|first=Andy|title=Gary Schiff loses campaign manager, fire department endorsement|url=http://blogs.citypages.com/blotter/2013/06/mpls_fire_dept_union_explains_pulling_schiff_endorsement.php|accessdate=September 24, 2013|newspaper=City Pages|date=June 17, 2013|df=}}</ref>
===Post-mayoral bid=== Schiff did not run for reelection in the [[Minneapolis City Council elections, 2013|City Council elections]] in 2013.<ref>{{cite news|last=Collins|first=Jon|title=In Minneapolis, 6 vie to replace councilman Gary Schiff|url=http://blogs.mprnews.org/cities/2013/11/in-minneapolis-6-vie-to-replace-councilman-gary-schiff/|accessdate=December 30, 2013|newspaper=''[[MPR News]]''|date=November 4, 2013}}</ref> Activist and communications specialist [[Alondra Cano]] won his seat with over 47 percent of the vote<ref>{{cite news|last=Boros|first=Karen|title=After three RCV counts, Minneapolis has seven new City Council members|url=http://www.minnpost.com/politics-policy/2013/11/after-three-rcv-counts-minneapolis-has-seven-new-city-council-members|accessdate=December 30, 2013|newspaper=MinnPost|date=November 8, 2013}}</ref> and was sworn into office on January 6, 2014.<ref>{{cite news|last=Roper|first=Eric|title=New era begins at Minneapolis City Hall|url=http://www.startribune.com/politics/statelocal/238878771.html|accessdate=January 6, 2014|newspaper=Star Tribune|date=January 6, 2014}}</ref>
===Council on Crime and Justice=== On July 1, 2014, Schiff took over as president of the Council on Crime and Justice (CCJ), a Minneapolis nonprofit organization established in 1957 to "create a criminal justice system that is equitable and just."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kimball|first1=Joe|title=Ex-City Council Member Gary Schiff to lead Council on Crime and Justice|url=http://www.minnpost.com/political-agenda/2014/06/ex-city-council-member-gary-schiff-lead-council-crime-and-justice|accessdate=July 14, 2014|work=[[MinnPost]]|date=June 26, 2014}}</ref> The CCJ dismissed Schiff in 2015 and closed suddenly in 2016 after almost 60 years of operation.<ref name="cano challengers" /><ref name="ccj closes" /> A federal audit conducted on a grant program that was frozen while Schiff led the CCJ identified a misuse of funds at the organization.<ref name="cano challengers" /> Schiff stated that he believed that the CCJ's board of directors and its previous leadership were responsible for the council's shutdown <ref name="cano challengers" />, however, [http://www.startribune.com/consultants-minneapolis-council-candidate-gary-schiff-was-involved-in-nonprofit-s-grant-problems/418577613/ staff accounts deviate].
===2017 City Council Candidacy=== In January 2017, Schiff announced a bid for the Minneapolis's 9th Ward City Council seat held by Alondra Cano.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Belz|first1=Adam|title=Ex-Council Member Gary Schiff runs for Alondra Cano's Ninth Ward seat|url=http://www.startribune.com/ex-council-member-gary-schiff-runs-for-alondra-cano-s-ninth-ward-seat/412063733/|accessdate=January 29, 2017|work=[[Star Tribune]]|date=January 28, 2017}}</ref> [http://www.minneapolismn.gov/ward9/index.htm Cano maintains her seat].
==Personal life== An avid cyclist, Schiff lives in the [[Corcoran, Minneapolis|Corcoran]] neighborhood of South Minneapolis.<ref name=uli>{{cite web|last=Berger|first=Gideon|title=Gary Schiff|url=http://www.uli.org/2009-2010-rose-fellow/uli-2009-2010-rose-center-fellow-gary-schiff/|publisher=Urban Land Institute|accessdate=November 20, 2012}}</ref> He sits on the board of [[In the Heart of the Beast Puppet and Mask Theatre]] and has served as co-chair of the capital campaign of the Little Earth for United Tribes.<ref name=uli /><ref>{{cite news|last1=Saterbak|first1=Bjorn|title=Former Council Member Gary Schiff takes new job as head of Council on Crime and Justice|url=http://www.journalmpls.com/news-feed/former-council-member-gary-schiff-takes-new-job-as-head-of-council-on-crime-and-justice|accessdate=July 14, 2014|work=[[Downtown Journal|The Journal]]|date=July 8, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140715222731/http://www.journalmpls.com/news-feed/former-council-member-gary-schiff-takes-new-job-as-head-of-council-on-crime-and-justice|archivedate=July 15, 2014|df=}}</ref> Schiff is gay<ref name=stribmayorannouncement /> and [[Gluten-free diet|does not eat gluten]].<ref name=growler>{{cite news|last=Zoss|first=Jeremy|title=Minneapolis Mayoral Candidates And Where They Stand on Beer|url=http://growlermag.com/minneapolis-mayoral-candidates/5/|accessdate=June 12, 2013|newspaper=The Growler|date=June 4, 2013}}</ref>

'''Gilla in Chomded húa Cormaic''', [[Gaels|Gaelic]]-[[Irish people|Irish]] [[poet]] of the early Middle Ages, fl. c. 1150 - c.1170.
==Biography== Gilla in Chomded was a [[poet]], [[scribe]] and [[scholar]] at the [[monastery]] of [[Tulach Léis]] (Tullylisk, [[County Down]]).
He authored the poem ''A Rí richid, réidig dam'', which has received extensive scholarly attention since the 19th century but still lacks a critical edition. It survives in the [[Book of Leinster]].<ref>[[Trinity College, Dublin|TCD]] MS 1339, previously H.2.18</ref>
''[[Aimirgin Glúngel tuir tend]]'' is another surviving poem credited to him.

{{about|the Wiccan deity|gods with horns or antlers on their heads|Horned deity}} [[File:Horned God.JPG|thumb|A sculpture of the Horned God Bucca of Cornish traditional witchcraft, found in the [[Museum of Witchcraft]] in [[Boscastle]], [[Cornwall]].]] The '''Horned God''' is one of the two primary deities found in [[Wicca]] and some related forms of [[Neopaganism]]. The term ''Horned God'' itself predates Wicca, and is an early 20th-century [[syncretism|syncretic]] term for a horned or antlered anthropomorphic god with partly [[pseudohistorical]] origins, partly based on historical [[Horned deity|horned deities]].Michael D. Bailey ''Witchcraft Historiography (review)'' in Magic, Ritual, and Witchcraft - Volume 3, Number 1, Summer 2008, pp. 81-85 The Horned God represents the [[God (Wicca)|male part]] of the religion's [[Wiccan ditheism|duotheistic theological system]], the [[Prince consort|consort]] of the female [[Triple Goddess (Neopaganism)|Triple Goddess]] of the Moon or other [[Mother Goddess]].{{cite web|url=http://www.druidry.org/library/gods-goddesses/horned-god-unofficial-autobiography |title=from the library of the Order of Bards, Ovates & Druids |publisher=Druidry.org |accessdate=2014-02-25}} In common Wiccan belief, he is associated with nature, wilderness, sexuality, hunting, and the life cycle.{{Cite book|title=The Witches' God: Lord of the Dance |publisher=Robert Hale |location=London |first=Janet |last=Farrar |author2=Farrar, Stewart |year=1989 |pages= |isbn=0-7090-3319-2 }}{{rp|32–34}} Whilst depictions of the deity vary, he is always shown with either [[horn (anatomy)|horn]]s or [[antler]]s upon his head, often depicted as being [[Theriocephaly|theriocephalic]] (having a beast's head), in this way emphasizing "the union of the divine and the animal", the latter of which includes [[human]]ity.{{Cite book|title=Horns of Power |publisher=Avalonia |location=London |first=Sorita |last=d'Este |year=2008 |pages=|isbn=1-905297-17-3}}{{rp|11}} In traditional Wicca ([[British Traditional Wicca]]), he is generally regarded as a [[Dualistic cosmology|dualistic]] god of twofold aspects: bright and dark, night and day, summer and winter, the Oak King and the [[Holly King (archetype)|Holly King]]. In this dualistic view, his two horns symbolize, in part, his dual nature. (The use of horns to symbolize duality is also reflected in the phrase "on the horns of a dilemma.") The three aspects of the Goddess and the two aspects of the Horned God are sometimes mapped on to the five points of the [[Pentagram]], although which points correspond to which deity aspects varies. In some other systems, he is represented as a [[triple deities|triune]] [[god]], split into three aspects that reflect those of the Triple Goddess: the [[wikt:youth|Youth]] ([[Warrior]]), the [[wikt:father|Father]], and the [[Sage (philosophy)|Sage]]. The Horned God has been explored within several [[psychology|psychological]] theories and has become a recurrent theme in [[fantasy]] literature. Clute, John ''The Encyclopedia of Fantasy'' {{Cite book |title=The Encyclopedia of Fantasy |publisher=Orbit |location= |first=John |last=Clute |author2=Grant, John |year=1997 |pages= |isbn=1-85723-368-9}} {{rp|872}} ==In Wicca== [[File:Gundestrup Cernunnos.jpg|thumb|The "Cernunnos" type antlered figure on the [[Gundestrup Cauldron]]]] In traditional and mainstream Wicca, the Horned God is viewed as the divine male principality, being both equal and opposite to the Goddess. The Wiccan god himself can be represented in many forms, including as the [[Solar deity|Sun God]], the Sacrificed God and the Vegetation God, although the Horned God is the most popular representation. The pioneers of the various Wiccan or Witchcraft traditions, such as [[Gerald Gardner (Wiccan)|Gerald Gardner]], [[Doreen Valiente]] and [[Roy Bowers|Robert Cochrane]], all claimed that their religion was a continuation of the [[Paganism|pagan]] religion of the [[Witch-Cult]] following historians who had purported the Witch-Cult's existence, such as [[Jules Michelet]] and [[Margaret Murray]]. For Wiccans, the Horned God is "the personification of the life force energy in animals and the wild""Starhawk" in News-Week On-faith [http://newsweek.washingtonpost.com/onfaith/starhawk/2006/11/some_basic_definitions.html Some basic definitions] 2006 and is associated with [[Lord of the animals|the wilderness]], virility and [[Hunting God|the hunt]]. {{Cite book |title=Introduction to Pagan Studies |publisher=AltaMira Press |location= |first=Barbara Jane |last=Davy |year=2006 |pages= |isbn=0-7591-0819-6}} {{rp|16}} [[Doreen Valiente]] writes that the Horned God also [[Psychopomp|carries the souls of the dead to the underworld]]. Wiccans generally, as well as some other neopagans, tend to conceive of the universe as polarized into gender opposites of [[masculinity|male]] and [[femininity|female]] [[Energy (esotericism)|energies]]. In traditional Wicca, the Horned God and the Goddess are seen as equal and opposite in gender polarity. However, in some of the newer traditions of Wicca, and especially those influenced by feminist ideology, there is more emphasis on the Goddess, and consequently the symbolism of the Horned God is less developed than that of the [[Goddess (Wicca)|Goddess]].{{Cite book |title=New Age Religion and Western Culture |publisher=State University of New York Press |location= |first=Wouter J. |last=Hanegraaff |year=1997 |pages= |isbn=0-7914-3854-6}}{{rp|154}} In Wicca the cycle of the seasons is celebrated during eight sabbats called The [[Wheel of the Year]]. The seasonal cycle is imagined to follow the relationship between the Horned God and the Goddess. The Horned God is born in winter, impregnates the Goddess and then dies during the autumn and winter months and is then reborn by the Goddess at Yule. {{Cite book |title=The Witches' bible |publisher=Robert Hale Ltd |location= |first=Janet |last=Farrer |author2=Stewart Farrer |year=2002 |pages= |isbn=0-7090-7227-9}} The different relationships throughout the year are sometimes distinguished by splitting the god into aspects, the Oak King and the Holly King. The relationships between the Goddess and the Horned God are mirrored by Wiccans in seasonal rituals. There is some variation between Wiccan groups as to which sabbat corresponds to which part of the cycle. Some Wiccans regard the Horned God as dying at Lammas, August 1; also known as Lughnasadh, which is the first harvest sabbat. Others may see him dying at Mabon, the [[autumn equinox]], or the second harvest festival. Still other Wiccans conceive of the Horned God dying on October 31, which Wiccans call [[Samhain]], the ritual of which is focused on death. He is then reborn on Winter Solstice, December 21. {{Cite book |title=Enchanted Feminism |publisher=Routledge |location= |first=Jone |last=Salomonsen |year=2001 |pages= |isbn=0-415-22393-8}} {{rp|190}} Other important dates for the Horned God include [[Imbolc]] when, according to Valiente, he leads a [[wild hunt]]. {{Cite book |title=The nature of magic |publisher=Berg Publishers |location= |first=Susan |last=Greenwood |year=2005 |pages= |isbn=1-84520-095-0}} {{rp|191}} In Gardnerian Wicca, the Dryghten prayer is recited at the end of every ritual meeting contains the lines referring to the Horned God: {{quote| In the name of the Lady of the Moon,
and the Horned Lord of Death and Resurrection }} According to [[Sabina Magliocco]], {{Cite book |title=Witching Culture |publisher=University of Pennsylvania Press |location= |first=Sabina |last=Magliocco |year=2004 |pages= |isbn=0-8122-3803-6}} {{rp|28}} [[Gerald Gardner (Wiccan)|Gerald Gardner]] says (in 1959's ''[[The Meaning of Witchcraft]]'') that The Horned God is an Under-god, a mediator between an unknowable supreme deity and the people. (In Wiccan liturgy in the Book of Shadows, this conception of an unknowable supreme deity is referred to as "Dryghtyn." It is not a personal god, but rather an impersonal divinity similar to the Tao of Taoism.) Whilst the Horned God is the most common depiction of masculine divinity in Wicca, he is not the only representation. Other examples include the [[Green Man]] and the [[solar deity|Sun God]]. In traditional Wicca, however, these other representations of the Wiccan god are subsumed or amalgamated into the Horned God, as aspects or expressions of him. Sometimes this is shown by adding horns or antlers to the iconography. The Green Man, for example, may be shown with branches resembling antlers; and the Sun God may be depicted with a crown or halo of solar rays, that may resemble horns. These other conceptions of the Wiccan god should not be regarded as displacing the Horned God, but rather as elaborating on various facets of his nature. Doreen Valiente has called the Horned God "the eldest of gods" in both The Witches Creed and also in her Invocation To The Horned God. Wiccans believe that The Horned God, as Lord of Death, is their "comforter and consoler" after death and before reincarnation; and that he rules the [[Underworld]] or [[The Summerland|Summerland]] where the souls of the dead reside as they await rebirth. Some, such as Joanne Pearson, believe that this is based on the [[Mesopotamian]] myth of [[Inanna]]'s [[Inanna#Inanna's descent to the underworld|descent into the underworld]], though this has not been confirmed. {{Cite book |title=A Popular Dictionary of Paganism |publisher=Routledge |location= |first=Joanne |last=Pearson |year=2002 |pages= |isbn=0-7007-1591-6}} {{rp|147}} ===Names=== [[File:Horned God and Mother Goddess (Doreen Valiente's Altar).jpg|thumb|right|Altar statues of the Horned God and Mother Goddess crafted by Bel Bucca and owned by the "Mother of Wicca", [[Doreen Valiente]]]] [[Doreen Valiente]], a former High Priestess of the [[Gardnerian Wicca|Gardnerian tradition]], claimed that Gerald Gardner's [[Bricket Wood coven]] referred to the god as [[Cernunnos]], or '''Kernunno''', which is a Latin word, discovered on a [[pillar of the Boatmen|stone carving found in France]], meaning "the Horned One". Valiente claimed that the coven also referred to the god as '''Janicot''',{{needs IPA}} which she theorised was of [[Basque language|Basque]] origin, and Gardner also used this name in his novel ''High Magic's Aid''.{{Cite book |title=The Rebirth of Witchcraft |publisher=Robert Hale Ltd |first=Doreen |last=Valiente |year=2007 |pages= |isbn=0-7090-8369-6 }}{{rp|52–53}} [[Stewart Farrar]], a High Priest of the [[Alexandrian Wicca|Alexandrian tradition]] referred to the Horned God as Karnayna, which he believed was a corruption of the word Cernunnos.{{Cite book |title=What Witches Do |publisher=Robert Hale Ltd |first=Stewart |last=Farrar |year=2010 |pages= |isbn=0-7090-9014-5}} The historian [[Ronald Hutton]] has suggested that it instead came from the Arabic term [[Dhul-Qarnayn]] which meant "Horned One". This term had been used in the [[Quran|Qur'an]] to refer to [[Cyrus the Great]] or alternatively [[Alexander the Great]], who considered himself the son of the horned deity Ammon-Zeus, and wore horns as a part of his regalia. Margaret Murray had mentioned this information in her 1933 book ''The God of the Witches'', and Hutton theorised that [[Alex Sanders (Wiccan)|Alex Sanders]] had taken it from there, enjoying the fact that he shared his name with the ancient Macedonian emperor.{{Cite book |title=The Triumph of the Moon: a History of Modern Pagan Witchcaraft |publisher=Oxford Paperbacks |first=Ronald |last=Hutton |year=1995 |pages= |isbn=0-19-285449-6 }}{{rp|331}} In the writings of [[Charles Cardell]] and [[Raymond Howard (Wiccan)|Raymond Howard]], the god was referred to as '''Atho'''. Howard had a wooden statue of Atho's head which he claimed was 2200 years old, but the statue was stolen in April 1967. Howard's son later admitted that his father had carved the statue himself.{{cite web |url=http://www.thewica.co.uk/coven_of_atho%20article.htm#_ednref22 |title=The Coven of Atho |publisher=Thewica.co.uk |accessdate=2014-02-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Z8swU6zn?url=http://www.thewica.co.uk/coven_of_atho%20article.htm |archivedate=2015-06-08 |df= }} In [[Cochrane's Craft]], which was founded by [[Robert Cochrane (witch)|Robert Cochrane]], the Horned God was often referred to by a Biblical name; [[Tubal-cain]], who, according to the [[Bible]] was the first blacksmith.{{Cite book |first=Mike |last=Howard |title=The Roebuck in the Thicket: An Anthology of the Robert Cochrane Witchcraft Tradition |publisher=Capall Bann Publishing |isbn=1-86163-155-3 |year=2001 }} Chapter One. In this neopagan concept, the god is also referred to as [[Brân the Blessed|Brân]], a Welsh mythological figure, [[Wayland the Smith|Wayland]], the smith in Germanic mythology, and [[Herne the Hunter|Herne]], a horned figure from [[English folklore]]. In the neopagan tradition of [[Stregheria]], founded by [[Raven Grimassi]] and loosely inspired by the works of [[Charles Godfrey Leland]], the Horned God goes by several names, including [[Janus|Dianus]], [[Faunus]], Cern, and [[Actaeon]].{{Citation needed|date=May 2010}} In the Hinduism, the Horned God is referred to [[Pashupati]], See [[Pashupati Seal]].{{Citation needed|date=March 2018}} ==In psychology== ===Jungian analysis=== [[File:Gehörnter Gott, Enkomi.jpg|thumb|upright|Bronze figurine of a "Horned God" from [[Enkomi]], Cyprus]] Sherry Salman considers the image of the Horned God in [[Jungian]] terms, as an archetypal protector and mediator of the outside world to the objective psyche. In her theory the male psyche's 'Horned God' frequently compensates for inadequate fathering. When first encountered, the figure is a dangerous, 'hairy chthonic wildman' possessed of kindness and intelligence. If [[psychological repression|repressed]], later in life The Horned God appears as the lord of the Otherworld, or [[Hades]]. If split off entirely, he leads to violence, substance abuse and sexual perversion. When integrated he gives the male an ego 'in possession of its own destructiveness' and for the female psyche gives an effective [[anima and animus|animus]] relating to both the physical body and the psyche. {{Cite book |title= The Inner World of Trauma |publisher=Routledge |location= |first=Donald |last=Kalsched |year=1996 |pages= |isbn=0-415-12329-1}} In considering the Horned God as a symbol recurring in women's literature, Richard Sugg suggests the Horned God represents the 'natural Eros', a masculine lover subjugating the social-conformist nature of the female shadow, thus encompassing a combination of the [[Shadow (psychology)|shadow]] and animus. One such example is [[Heathcliff (Wuthering Heights)|Heathcliff]] from [[Emily Brontë]]'s ''[[Wuthering Heights]]''. Sugg goes on to note that female characters who are paired with this character usually end up socially ostracised, or worse – in an inverted ending to the male hero-story. {{Cite book |title=Jungian Literary Criticism |publisher=Northwestern University Press |location= |first=Richard |last=Sugg |year=1994 |pages= |isbn=0-8101-1042-3}} {{rp|162}} ===Humanistic psychology=== Following the work of [[Robert Bly]] in the [[Mythopoetic men's movement]], [[John Rowan (psychologist)|John Rowan]] proposes the Horned God as a "[[Woodwose|Wild Man]]" be used as a fantasy image or "sub-personality" {{Cite book |title=Discover your sub-personalities |publisher=Routledge |location= |first=John |last=Rowan |year=1993 |pages= |isbn=0-415-07366-9}} {{rp|38}} helpful to men in [[humanistic psychology]], and escaping from "narrow societal images of masculinity" {{Cite book |title=Healing the Male Psyche |publisher=Routledge |location= |first=John |last=Rowan |year=1996 |pages= |isbn=0-415-10049-6}} {{rp|249}} encompassing excessive deference to women and [[paraphillia]].{{rp|57-57}} ==Theories of historical origins== [[File:Star_Carr_headdress_cropped.JPG|thumb|A red deer headdress from [[Star Carr]]. Many of the 20 other headdresses have more complex sets of antlers.]] [[File:Pintura Trois Freres.jpg|thumb|upright|Sketch of Breuil's drawing]] [[horned deity|Many horned deities]] are known to have been worshipped in various cultures throughout history. Evidence for horned gods appear very early in the human record. The so-called [[The Sorcerer (cave art)|Sorcerer]] dates from perhaps 13,000 BCE. Twenty-one red deer headdresses, made from the skulls of the [[red deer]] and likely fitted with leather laces, have been uncovered at the Mesolithic site of [[Star Carr]]. They are thought to date from roughly 9,000 BCE.{{cite web |url=http://www.teachinghistory100.org/objects/about_the_object/mesolithic_headdress |title=British Museum headdresses |website= |publisher=Trustees of the British Museum |access-date=2018-01-17 |quote=}} Several theories have been created to establish historical roots for modern [[Neopagan]] worship of a Horned God. ===Margaret Murray=== Following the writings of [[suffragist]] [[Matilda Joslyn Gage]] {{Cite book |title=Woman, Church and State |publisher=Forgotten Books |location= |first=Matilda |last=Gage |year=2008 |pages= |isbn=1-60620-191-3}} and others, [[Margaret Murray]], in her 1921 book ''[[The Witch-Cult in Western Europe]]'', proposed the theory that the witches of the early-modern period were remnants of a pagan cult and that the Christian Church had declared the god of the witches was in fact [[the Devil]]. Without recourse to any specific representation of this deity, Murray speculates that the head coverings common in [[inquisition]]-derived descriptions of the devil "may throw light on one of the possible origins of the cult."{{Cite book|authorlink=Margaret Murray |last=Murray |first=Margaret |title=The Witch-cult in Western Europe (1921)|year=2006|publisher=Standard Publications|isbn=1-59462-126-8}} [[File:Nejamesa horned god of India.png|thumb|left|Horned God [[Naigamesha]] of the Indian sub-religion [[Kaumaram]]. Possibly from the Shunga period (1st-2nd century B.C), or earlier]] In 1931 Murray published a sequel, ''The God of the Witches'', which tries to gather evidence in support of her witch-cult theory. In Chapter 1 "The Horned God".{{Cite book|last=Murray |first=Margaret |title=The God of the Witches (1931)|year=1970|isbn=0-19-501270-4|publisher=OUA USA}} Murray claims that various depictions of humans with horns from [[Europe]]an and [[India]]n sources, ranging from the [[paleolithic]] French cave painting of "[[The Sorcerer (cave art)|The Sorcerer]]" to the Indic [[Pashupati]] to the modern English [[Dorset Ooser]], are evidence for an unbroken, Europe-wide tradition of worship of a singular Horned God. Murray derived this model of a horned god cult from [[James Frazer]] and [[Jules Michelet]]. {{Cite book |title=The Witch in History |publisher=Routledge |location= |first=Diane |last=Purkiss |year=2006 |pages= |isbn=0-415-08762-7}} {{rp|36}} In dealing with "[[The Sorcerer (cave art)|The Sorcerer]]",{{rp|23–4}} the earliest evidence claimed, Murray based her observations on a drawing by [[Henri Breuil]], which some modern scholars such as Ronald Hutton claim is inaccurate. Hutton states that modern photographs show the original cave art lacks horns, a human torso or any other significant detail on its upper half. {{Cite book |title=Witches, Druids, and King Arthur |publisher=Hambledon Continuum |location= |first=Ronald |last=Hutton |year=2006 |pages= |isbn=1-85285-555-X}} {{rp|34}} However, others, such as celebrated prehistorian [[Jean Clottes]], assert that Breuil's sketch is indeed accurate. Clottes stated that "I have seen it myself perhaps 20 times over the years".{{cite web|url=http://www.strangehistory.net/2011/07/06/cave-art-cobblers/|title=Cave Art Cobblers? - Beachcombing's Bizarre History Blog|date=6 July 2011|publisher=}} Breuil considered his drawing to represent a shaman or magician - an interpretation which gives the image its name. Murray having seen the drawing called Breuil's image "the first depiction of a deity", an idea which Breuil and others later adopted. Murray also used an inaccurate drawing of a [[mesolithic]] rock-painting at [[El Cogul|Cogul]] in northeast Spain as evidence of group religious ceremony of the cult, although the central male figure is not horned.{{rp|65}} The illustration she used of the Cogul painting leaves out a number of figures, human and animal, and the original is more likely a sequence of superimposed but unrelated illustrations, rather than a depiction of a single scene.{{rp|197}} Despite widespread criticism of Murray's scholarship some minor aspects of her work continued to have supporters.{{Cite book|last=Ginzburg |first=Carlo |authorlink=Carlo Ginzburg |title=Ecstasies: Deciphering the Witches' Sabbath}}{{rp|9}}"Other historians, like Byloff and Bonomo, have been willing to build upon the useful aspects of Murray's work without adopting its untenable elements, and the independent and careful researches of contemporary scholars have lent aspects of the Murray thesis considerable new strength." — J. B. Russell (1972) ''Witchcraft in the Middle Ages''. Cornell University Press. p.37. ====Influences from literature==== The popular image of the Greek god [[Pan (god)|Pan]] was removed from its classical context in the writings of the [[Romantics]] of the 18th century and connected with their ideals of a pastoral England. This, along with the general public's increasing lack of familiarity of [[Greek mythology]] at the time led to the figure of Pan becoming generalised as a 'horned god', and applying connotations to the character, such as benevolence that were not evident in the original Greek myths which in turn gave rise to the popular acceptance of Murray's hypothetical horned god of the witches. {{Main|Aradia, or the Gospel of the Witches#Influence on Wicca and Stregheria}} The reception of ''Aradia'' amongst Neopagans has not been entirely positive. Clifton suggests that modern claims of revealing an Italian pagan witchcraft tradition, for example those of [[Leo Martello]] and [[Raven Grimassi]], must be "match[ed] against", and compared with the claims in ''Aradia''. He further suggests that a lack of comfort with ''Aradia'' may be due to an "insecurity" within Neopaganism about the movement's claim to authenticity as a religious revival. {{Cite book |title=The Paganism reader |publisher=Routledge |location= |first=Chas |last=Clifton |author2=Harvey, Graham |year=2004 |pages= |isbn=0-415-30353-2}} {{rp|61}} [[File:Chaire Cathédrale Liège 240809 04.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Lucifer]] ''([[Le génie du mal]])'' by [[Guillaume Geefs]] (Cathedral of St. Paul, [[Liège]], Belgium)]] Valiente offers another explanation for the negative reaction of some neopagans; that the identification of [[Lucifer]] as the god of the witches in ''Aradia'' was "too strong meat" for Wiccans who were used to the gentler, romantic paganism of Gerald Gardner and were especially quick to reject any relationship between witchcraft and [[Satanism]].[[Doreen Valiente|Valiente, Doreen]], quoted in Clifton, p. 61. {{main|Witch-cult hypothesis#Post-Murray}} In 1985 Classical historian [[Georg Luck]], in his ''Arcana Mundi: Magic and the Occult in the Greek and Roman Worlds'', theorised that the origins of the Witch-cult may have appeared in late antiquity as a faith primarily designed to worship the Horned God, stemming from the merging of [[Cernunnos]], a horned god of the Celts, with the Greco-Roman [[Pan (god)|Pan]]/[[Faunus]], a combination of gods which he posits created a new deity, around which the remaining [[pagan]]s, those refusing to convert to Christianity, rallied and that this deity provided the prototype for later Christian conceptions of the [[Devil]], and his worshippers were cast by the Church as witches. ====Influences from occultism==== [[Image:Baphomet.png|thumb|upright|The 19th century image of a Sabbatic Goat, created by [[Eliphas Levi|Eliphas Lévi]]. Baphomet serves as an historical model for Murray's concept.]] Eliphas Levi's image of "[[Baphomet]]" serves as an example of the transformation of the Devil into a benevolent fertility deity and provided the prototype for Murray's horned god. Murray's central thesis that images of the Devil were actually of [[deities]] and that [[Christianity]] had demonised these worshippers as following [[Satan]], is first recorded in the work of Levi in the fashionable 19th-century [[Occult]]ist circles of England and France.Juliette Wood, "[http://www.juliettewood.com/papers/Tarot.pdf The Celtic Tarot and the Secret Traditions: A Study in Modern Legend Making]": ''Folklore'', Vol. 109, 1998 Levi created his image of Baphomet, published in his ''[[Dogme et Rituel de la Haute Magie]]'' (1855), by combining symbolism from diverse traditions, including the ''[[The Devil (Tarot card)|Diable]]'' card of the 16th and 17th century [[Tarot of Marseille]]. Lévi called his image "The Goat of Mendes", possibly following [[Herodotus]]' accountHerodotus, ''Histories'' ii. 42, 46 and 166. that the god of Mendes—the Greek name for Djedet, Egypt—was depicted with a goat's face and legs. Herodotus relates how all male goats were held in great reverence by the Mendesians, and how in his time a woman publicly [[Zoophilia|copulated with a goat]].Herodotus, ''Histories'' ii. 46. [[Plutarch]] specifically associates [[Osiris]] with the "goat at Mendes." [http://www.sacred-texts.com/gno/th1/th140.htm ''De Iside et Osiride'', lxxiii.] [[E. A. Wallis Budge]] writes, {{quote|At several places in the Delta, e.g. Hermopolis, Lycopolis, and Mendes, the god Pan and a goat were worshipped; Strabo, quoting (xvii. 1, 19) Pindar, says that in these places goats had intercourse with women, and Herodotus (ii. 46) instances a case which was said to have taken place in the open day. The Mendisians, according to this last writer, paid reverence to all goats, and more to the males than to the females, and particularly to one he-goat, on the death of which public mourning is observed throughout the whole Mendesian district; they call both Pan and the goat Mendes, and both were worshipped as gods of generation and fecundity. Diodorus ([http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Diodorus_Siculus/1D*.html#ref32 i. 88]) compares the cult of the goat of Mendes with that of Priapus, and groups the god with the Pans and the Satyrs. The goat referred to by all these writers is the famous Mendean Ram, or Ram of Mendes, the cult of which was, according to Manetho, established by Kakau, the king of the IInd dynasty.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6SBLAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA353|title=The Gods of the Egyptians: Or, Studies in Egyptian Mythology|first=Sir Ernest Alfred Wallis|last=Budge|date=28 July 2018|publisher=Methuen & Company|via=Google Books}}}} Historically, the deity that was venerated at Egyptian Mendes was a ram deity [[Banebdjedet]] (literally Ba of the lord of djed, and titled "the Lord of Mendes"), who was the soul of [[Osiris]]. Lévi combined the images of the Tarot of Marseilles Devil card and refigured the ram ''Banebdjed'' as a he-goat, further imagined by him as "copulator in Anep and inseminator in the district of Mendes". ===Gerald Gardner and Wicca=== [[Margaret Murray]]'s theory of the historical origins of the Horned God has been used by Wiccans to create a myth of historical origins for their religion.{{rp|110}} There is no verifiable evidence to support claims that the religion originates earlier than the mid-20th century. {{Main|Wicca#Theology}} Modern scholarship has disproved Margaret Murray's theory, however various horned gods and mother goddesses were indeed worshipped in the British Isles during the ancient and early Medieval periods.{{cite book |title=The Pagan Religions of the Ancient British Isles |publisher=Blackwell |location= |first=Ronald |last=Hutton |year=1991 |pages=260–261 |isbn=0-631-17288-2}} The "father of Wicca", [[Gerald Gardner (Wiccan)|Gerald Gardner]], who adopted Margaret Murray's thesis, claimed Wicca was a modern survival of an ancient pan-European pagan religion.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rLYCOOUlsBcC&pg=PA6#PPA6,M1 |title=Nature Religion Today: Paganism in the Modern World |first=Joanne |last=Pearson |author2=Roberts, Richard H |author3=Samuel, Geoffrey |publisher=Edinburgh University Press |location=Edinburgh |page=172 |date=December 1998 |isbn=0-7486-1057-X |oclc=39533917}} Gardner states that he had reconstructed elements of the religion from fragments, incorporating elements from [[Freemasonry]], the [[Occult]], and [[Theosophy (Blavatskian)|Theosophy]], which came together in the [[Hermetic Order of the Golden Dawn]], where Gardner met [[Aleister Crowley]], whose influence became the basis for Wiccan magical practices. {{Cite book |title=Teenage Witches: Magical Youth and the Search for the Self |publisher=Rutgers University Press |location= |first=Helen |last=Berger |author2=Ezzy, Douglas |year=2007 |pages= |isbn=0-8135-4021-6}} {{rp|27}} {{Main|Aleister Crowley#Occult}} Gerald Gardner was initiated into [[Ordo Templi Orientis|the O.T.O.]] by Aleister Crowley and subsequently went on to found the Neopagan religion of Wicca. Various scholars on early Wiccan history, such as [[Ronald Hutton]], [[Philip Heselton]], and [[Leo Ruickbie]] concur that witchcraft's early rituals, as devised by Gardner, contained much from Crowley's writings such as the [[Liber XV, The Gnostic Mass|Gnostic Mass]]. The third degree initiation ceremony in Gardnerian Wicca (including the [[Great Rite]]) is derived almost completely from the Gnostic Mass.{{cite web|url=http://www.eocto.org/article/101 |title=Ecclesia Ordinis Caelestis Templum Olympicus - Thelemic Origins of Wicca |publisher=Eocto.org |accessdate=2014-02-25}} ===Romano-Celtic fusion=== Georg Luck, repeats part of Murray's theory, stating that the Horned God may have appeared in late antiquity, stemming from the merging of [[Cernunnos]], an antlered god of the Continental Celts, with the Greco-Roman [[Pan (god)|Pan]]/[[Faunus]],{{Cite book|authorlink=Georg Luck |last=Luck |first=Georg |year=1985 |title=Arcana Mundi: Magic and the Occult in the Greek and Roman Worlds: A Collection of Ancient Texts. |location=Baltimore, MD |publisher=Johns Hopkins University Press |pages=6–7}} a combination of gods which he posits created a new deity, around which the remaining pagans, those refusing to convert to Christianity, rallied and that this deity provided the prototype for later Christian conceptions of [[Devil|the devil]], and his worshippers were cast by the Church as witches. ==Art, fantasy and science fiction== [[Image:Francisco de Goya y Lucientes - Witches' Sabbath - WGA10007.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Francisco de Goya]]'s ''[[Witches' Sabbath (1789)|Witches Sabbat]]'' (1789), which depicts [[the Devil]] flanked by Satanic witches. The Witch Cult hypothesis states that such stories are based upon a real-life pagan cult that revered a horned god]] In 1908's ''[[The Wind in the Willows]]'' by [[Kenneth Grahame]], in Chapter 7, "The Piper at the Gates of Dawn", Ratty and Mole meet a mystical horned being, powerful, fearsome and kind.{{rp|85}} Grahame's work was a significant part of the cultural milieu which stripped the Greek god Pan of his cultural identity in favor of an unnamed, generic horned deity which led to Murray's thesis of historical origins. Outside of works that predate the publication of Murray's thesis, horned god motifs and characters appear in fantasy literature that draws upon her work and that of her followers. In the novel ''[[Childhood's End]]'' (1953) by [[Arthur C. Clarke]], all humans have a collective premonition, also described as a memory of the future, of horned aliens which arrive to usher in a new phase of human evolution. The collective subconscious image of the horned aliens is what accounts for mankind's image of the devil or Satan. This theme is also explored in the ''[[Doctor Who]]'' story ''[[The Dæmons]]'' in 1971, where the local superstitions around a landmark known as The Devil's Hump prove to be based on reality, as aliens from the planet Dæmos have been affecting man's progress over the millennia and the Hump actually contains a spacecraft. The only Dæmon to appear is a classic interpretation of a horned satyr-like being with hooves. In the critically acclaimed and influential 1950s TV series created by [[Nigel Kneale]], ''[[Quatermass and the Pit]]'', depictions of supernatural horned entities, with specific reference to prehistoric cave-art and shamanistic horned head-dress are revealed to be a "race-memory" of psychic [[Martian]] grasshoppers, manifested at the climax of the film by a fiery horned god.White, Eric (1996) ''Once they were men: Now they're Landcrabs: Monsterous Becomings in Evolutionist Cinema'', in {{Cite book |title=Posthuman Bodies |publisher=John Wiley & Sons |location= |first=J |last=Halberstam |year=1996 |pages= |isbn=0-253-20970-6}} {{rp|244}} Murray's theories has been seen to have had influence on ''[[The Blood on Satan's Claw]]'' (1971), where a murderous female-led cult worships a horned deity named [[Behemoth]]. Hunt, Leon (2001) ''Necromancy in the UK: Witchcraft and the occult in British horror'', in {{Cite book |title=British Horror Cinema |publisher=Routledge |location= |first=Steve |last=Chibnall |author2=Petley, Julian |year=2001 |pages= |isbn=0-415-23004-7}} {{rp|94}} [[Marion Zimmer Bradley]], who acknowledges the influence of Murray, uses the figure of the "horned god" in her feminist fantasy transformation of [[King Arthur|Arthurian myth]], ''[[Mists of Avalon]]'' (1984), and portrays ritualistic incest between King Arthur as the representative of the horned god and his sister [[Morgan le Fay|Morgaine]] as the "spring maiden". {{Cite book |title=The Search for a Woman-centered Spirituality |publisher=New York University Press |location= |first=Annette |last=van Dyke |year=1992 |pages= |isbn=0-8147-8770-3}} {{rp|106}} In the popular video game ''[[The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind|Morrowind]]'', its expansion ''[[The Elder Scrolls III: Bloodmoon|Bloodmoon]]'' has a plot enemy known as Hircine, the Daedric god of the Hunt, who appears as a horned man with the face of a deer skull. He condemned his "hounds" ([[werewolves]]) to walk the mortal ground during the Bloodmoon until a champion defeats him or Bloodmoon falls. When in combat, Hircine appears as a horned wolf or bear. The 1992 ''[[Discworld]]'' novel ''[[Lords and Ladies (novel)|Lords and Ladies]]'', by [[Terry Pratchett]], features a King of the Elves who is strongly reminiscent of the Horned God. Although not worshipped by [[Witches (Discworld)|the witches]] who are the heroines of the book (indeed, quite the reverse), they temporarily ally themselves with him out of necessity. ==See also== {{div col}} *[[Dionysus]] *[[Cernunnos]] *[[Green Man]] *[[Herne the Hunter]] *[[Horned deity|Horned deity (mythology)]] *[[Horned helmet]] *[[Krampus]] *[[Pan (god)|Pan]] *[[Satyr]] *[[Triple Goddess (Neopaganism)]] *[[Enki]] {{div col end}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commonscatinline}} {{WiccaandWitchcraft}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Death gods]] [[Category:Fantasy tropes]] [[Category:Horned deities]] [[Category:Hunting gods]] [[Category:Mythological hybrids]] [[Category:Nature gods]] [[Category:Pseudohistory]] [[Category:Solar gods]] [[Category:Wicca]]

'''Hypsicrates''' the historian was a [[Greek people|Greek]] writer in [[Ancient Rome|Rome]] who flourished in the 1st century [[Before Christ|BC]]. His work does not survive, but scholars have conjectures about the writer and his work. He was associated probably with [[Kingdom of Pontus|Pontus]] and wrote a history of the area that was possibly used by [[Strabo]]. He may be the same Hypsicrates who served as a [[slave]] for [[Julius Caesar]] and was freed by Caesar in 47 BC.
==References== *McDonald, Alexander Hugh and Simon Hornblower. "Hypsicrates" in Hornblower, Simon and Antony Spawforth, eds. ''The Oxford Classical Dictionary.'' London: [[OUP]], 2003. p. 739 *"Hypsikrates" in Ziegler, Konrat and Walther Sontheimer, eds. ''Der kleine Pauly.'' Munich: Artemis Verlag, 1975.
