'''Jean-Baptiste Gramaye''' ([[Antwerp]], 1579 - [[Lübeck]], 1635) was an early modern historian of the [[Southern Netherlands]]. He studied law and became a professor at [[Old University of Leuven|Leuven University]]. Later he was employed as [[historiographer royal|court historian]] by [[Albert VII, Archduke of Austria]]. For five months in 1619 he was a prisoner in Barbary, an experience that changed the focus of his scholarship from the Low Countries to Africa.<ref>Abd El Hadi Ben Mansour, ''Alger XVIe-XVIIe siècle, Journal de Jean-Baptiste Gramaye "évêque d'Afrique"'' (Paris, 1998)</ref>
==Works== *''Andromede Belgica dicta Alberto Austriaco, Isabellae Clarae Eugeniae acta a Falconis alumnis, tertio ab inauguratis principibus die'' (Leuven, [[Laurence Kellam]], 1600) *''Asia, sive historia universalis Asiaticarum gentium et rerum domi forisque gestarum'' (Brussels, Widow and Heirs of Joannes Bellerus, 1604) [https://books.google.com/books?id=PsxCAAAAcAAJ Available on Google Books] *''Gallo-Brabantia'' (Brussels, [[Jan Mommaert]], 1606) [https://books.google.com/books?id=eMVr4NXxmQAC Available on Google Books] *''Bruxella cum suo comitatu'' (Brussels, Jan Mommaert, 1606) [https://books.google.com/books?id=G5AoRvrymnAC Available on Google Books] *''Thenae et Brabantia ultra velpam quae olim Hasbaniae pars'' (Brussels, Jan Mommaert, 1606) [https://books.google.com/books?id=rysU4Vtjy-cC Available on Google Books] *''Arscotum Ducatus cum suis Baronatibus'' (Brussels, Jan Mommaert, 1606) [https://books.google.com/books?id=cWVAAAAAcAAJ Available on Google Books] *''Historia Brabantica'' (Leuven, [[Joannes Masius]], 1607) [https://books.google.com/books?id=oltbAAAAQAAJ Available on Google Books] *''Antverpiae antiquitates'' (Brussels, Jan Mommaert, 1610) [https://books.google.com/books?id=N2JAAAAAcAAJ Available on Google Books] *''Antiquitates illustrissimi ducatus Brabantiae'' (Brussels, Jan Mommaert, 1610) [https://books.google.com/books?id=OmJAAAAAcAAJ Available on Google Books] *''Taxandria'' (Brussels, [[Rutger Velpius]], 1610) [https://books.google.com/books?id=hiBhAAAAcAAJ Available on Google Books] *''Flandria Franca'' (Lille, [[Christophe Beys]], 1612) [https://books.google.com/books?id=oE1bAAAAQAAJ Available on Google Books] *''Rerum Duacensium Libri Tres'' (Douai, [[Jean Bogard]]; Antwerp, [[Hieronymus Verdussen]]; etc., 1618) [https://books.google.com/books?id=YWJAAAAAcAAJ Available on Google Books] *''Africae illustratae libri decem'' (Tournai, Adrien Quinque, 1622) [https://books.google.com/books?id=QWpVAAAAcAAJ Available on Google Books] *''Respublica Namurcensis, Hannoniae et Lutsenburgensis'' (Amsterdam, Jan Janssens, 1634) [https://books.google.com/books?id=hHslZMNY804C Available on Google Books] *''Antiquitates belgicae'', published posthumously, 1708.

{{Use American English|date=May 2018}} {{Use mdy dates|date=April 2018}} {{Infobox U.S. legislation | name = Jerusalem Embassy Act of 1995 | fullname = An act to provide for the relocation of the United States Embassy in Israel to Jerusalem, and for other purposes. | acronym = JEA | enacted by = 104th | effective date = November 8, 1995. | public law url = http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/PLAW-104publ45/content-detail.html | cite public law = 104–45 | cite statutes at large = 109 Stat. 398 | acts amended = None | title amended = None | sections created = None | sections amended = | leghisturl = http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d104:SN01322:@@@Z | introducedin = Senate | introducedbill = [http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d104:SN01322: S. 1322] | introducedby = [[Bob Dole]] ([[Republican Party (United States)|R]]-[[Kansas|KS]]) | introduceddate = October 13, 1995 | committees = [[United States Senate Committee on Foreign Relations|Senate Committee on Foreign Relations]], and [[United States House Committee on Foreign Affairs|House Committee on International Relations]] | passedbody1 = Senate | passeddate1 = October 24, 1995 | passedvote1 = 93–5
{{USSRollCall|104|1|496}} | passedbody2 = House | passeddate2 = October 24, 1995 | passedvote2 = 374–37
{{USHRollCall|1995|734}} | conferencedate = | passedbody3 = | passeddate3 = | passedvote3 = | agreedbody3 = | agreeddate3 = | agreedvote3 = | agreedbody4 = | agreeddate4 = | agreedvote4 = | passedbody4 = | passeddate4 = | passedvote4 = | unsignedpresident = [[Bill Clinton]] | unsigneddate = November 8, 1995 | amendments = }} The '''Jerusalem Embassy Act of 1995'''Jerusalem Embassy Act of 1995, {{USPL|104|45}}, November 8, 1995, 109 Stat. 398. is a public law of the [[United States]] passed by the post-[[Republican Revolution]] [[104th United States Congress|104th Congress]] on October 23, 1995. The proposed law was adopted by the [[United States Senate|Senate]] (93–5),On the passage of {{USBill |104|S.|1322}}, the Jerusalem Embassy Act of 1995, {{USSRollCall |104|1|496}} and the [[United States House of Representatives|House]] (374–37).On the passage of {{USBill |104|S.|1322}}, the Jerusalem Embassy Act of 1995, {{USHRollCall|1995|734}} The Act became law without a presidential signature on November 8, 1995. The Act recognized Jerusalem as the capital of the State of Israel and called for Jerusalem to remain an undivided city. Its purpose was to set aside funds for the relocation of the [[Embassy of the United States, Jerusalem|Embassy of the United States in Israel]] from [[Tel Aviv Branch Office of the Embassy of the United States|its location]] in [[Tel Aviv]] to [[Jerusalem]], by May 31, 1999. For this purpose it withheld 50% of the funds appropriated to the State Department specifically for "Acquisition and Maintenance of Buildings Abroad" as allocated in fiscal year 1999 until the United States Embassy in Jerusalem had officially opened.{{cite journal |first1=Marshall J. |last1=Breger |title=Jerusalem Gambit: How We Should Treat Jerusalem Is a Matter of U.S. Constitutional Law as Well as Middle Eastern Politics |journal=National Review |date=October 23, 1995 |volume=47 |issue=20 |pages=41–4}} Israel's declared capital is Jerusalem, but this is not internationally recognized, pending final status talks in the [[Israeli–Palestinian conflict]]. Despite passage, the law allowed the President to invoke a six-month waiver of the application of the law, and reissue the waiver every six months on "national security" grounds. The waiver was repeatedly renewed by Presidents [[Bill Clinton|Clinton]], [[George W. Bush|Bush]], and [[Barack Obama|Obama]].{{cite web|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2017/06/01/presidential-memorandum-secretary-state|title=Presidential Memorandum for the Secretary of State|date=June 1, 2017|website=Whitehouse.gov|accessdate=December 7, 2017}} President [[Donald Trump]] signed a waiver in June 2017. On June 5, 2017, the U.S. Senate unanimously passed a resolution commemorating the 50th anniversary of reunification of Jerusalem by 90-0. The resolution reaffirmed the Jerusalem Embassy Act and called upon the President and all United States officials to abide by its provisions.{{cite web|url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/senate-unanimously-passes-bill-marking-50-years-since-jerusalem-reunification/|title=Senate unanimously passes bill marking 50 years since Jerusalem reunification|website=The Times of Israel|accessdate=December 7, 2017}} On December 6, 2017, Trump [[United States recognition of Jerusalem as Israeli capital|recognized Jerusalem as Israel's capital]],Proclamation 9683 of December 6, 2017, [https://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/FR-2017-12-11/pdf/2017-26832.pdf#page=1 82 FR 58331] and ordered the planning of the relocation of the embassy.{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2017/12/06/trump-officially-recognizes-jerusalem-as-israels-capital-orders-us-embassy-move.html|title=Trump officially recognizes Jerusalem as Israel's capital, orders embassy move for US|first=Alex|last=Pappas|date=December 6, 2017|website=Foxnews.com|accessdate=December 7, 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/trump-signs-waiver-to-keep-us-embassy-in-tel-aviv/|title=Trump signs waiver, won't move US embassy to Jerusalem|website=Timesofisrael.com|accessdate=December 7, 2017}} However, following the announcement, Trump signed an embassy waiver again, delaying the move, as mandated by the Act, by at least six months.Presidential Determination No. 2018-2 December 6, 2017 [https://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/FR-2017-12-26/pdf/2017-28027.pdf#page=1 82 FR 61127] Legally, however, the U.S. embassy can be moved at any time without reliance on the Act. On February 23, 2018, President Trump announced that the US Embassy in Israel would reopen at the [[Arnona]] consular services site of the then [[Consulate General of the United States, Jerusalem|US Consulate-General]] in Jerusalem. The [[Embassy of the United States, Jerusalem|United States Embassy]] officially relocated to Jerusalem on May 14, 2018, to coincide with the 70th anniversary of the [[Israeli Declaration of Independence]].{{cite web|last1=Nauert|first1=Heather|title=Opening of U.S. Embassy Jerusalem|url=https://www.state.gov/r/pa/prs/ps/2018/02/278825.htm|publisher=[[United States Department of State]]|accessdate=February 25, 2018}}{{cite news|last1=Wadhams|first1=Nick|title=U.S. Speeds Up Timetable for Moving Embassy to Jerusalem|url=http://time.com/5174043/us-embassy-jerusalem-may/|accessdate=February 26, 2018|publisher=[[Time (magazine)|TIME]]|date=February 24, 2018}} ==Background== {{Jerusalem large}} {{main|Positions on Jerusalem#United States|l1=United States positions on Jerusalem}} Jerusalem holds unique spiritual and religious interests, such as [[Holy Places]] and religious buildings or sites, among the world's [[Abrahamic religions]] of [[Judaism]], [[Christianity]], and [[Islam]]. Following World War I, the victorious Principal Allied Powers recognized these as "a sacred trust of civilization", and stipulated that the existing rights and claims connected with them should be safeguarded in perpetuity, under international guarantee.{{citation | at = Article 28 | title = League of Nations Mandate for Palestine | url = http://avalon.law.yale.edu/20th_century/palmanda.asp#art28}}.{{citation | publisher = ICJ | title = Reports | year = 2004 | contribution = Construction of a wall (advisory opinion) | pages = 165 para. 70, 188 para. 129.}}{{citation | first = Paul JIM | last = de Waart | quote = The Court ascertained the legal significance of the 'sacred trust of civilization' of the League of Nations (LoN) in respect of the 1922 Palestine Mandate as the origin of the present responsibility of the United Nations | title = International Court of Justice Firmly Walled in the Law of Power in the Israeli–Palestinian Peace Process | journal = Leiden Journal of International Law | volume = 18 |issue=3 | year = 2005 | pages = 467–87 |doi=10.1017/S0922156505002839}}. The terms of the British [[Balfour Declaration of 1917]] were included in the [[British Mandate for Palestine (legal instrument)|Mandate for Palestine]] by the [[League of Nations]]. The US government was not a party to these agreements; but stated official foreign policy in 1919 was to 'acquiesce' in the Balfour Declaration, but not officially support [[Streams of Zionism|Zionism]].Walworth (1986) 473-83, esp. p. 481; Melvin I. Urofsky, ''American Zionism from Herzl to the Holocaust,'' (1995) ch. 6.{{citation | first = Frank W | last = Brecher | title = Reluctant Ally: United States Foreign Policy toward the Jews from Wilson to Roosevelt | year = 1991 | chapter = 1–4}}. On September 21, 1922, the [[US Congress]] passed a [[joint resolution]] stating its support for a homeland in Palestine for the Jewish people but not at the expense of other cultures present at the time.{{citation | url = http://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?title=File%3AUnited_States_Statutes_at_Large_Volume_42_Part_1.djvu&page=1040 | title = Pub. Resolution No. 73, 42 Stat. 1018 | chapter = 372}}.{{cite book | last= Rubenberg | first = Cheryl A | authorlink = Cheryl A. Rubenberg | year=1986 | title= Israel and the American National Interest: A Critical Examination | publisher= [[University of Illinois Press]] | isbn=0-252-06074-1 | pages= 27 }} This occurred virtually the same day the Palestine Mandate was approved by the [[League of Nations]]; although [[King-Crane Commission|official government findings]] about the affected peoples' choices concerning self-determination were available in government circles, they were withheld from the public until the following December.{{Cite web|author1=William T. Ellis, Introduction|authorlink1= William T. Ellis|author2=|title=Crane and King' Long-Hid Report on the Near East|agency=[[Editor & Publisher|The Editor and Publisher]]|website=[[NYTimes.com]]|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1922/12/03/109339098.pdf|publisher=[[The New York Times]]|date=December 3, 1922|accessdate=August 24, 2013| format=PDF}} US foreign policy remained unchanged. These competing nationalist claims led to increasing civil violence during the inter-war period; following World War II, the "Question of Palestine" was placed before the [[United Nations]], as the League's successor agency. On November 29, 1947, the UN General Assembly adopted Resolution 181, the [[United Nations Partition Plan for Palestine]]; it contained a recommendation that Jerusalem be placed under a [[Corpus separatum (Jerusalem)|special international regime, a corpus separatum, administered by the United Nations and be separate from both the Jewish and Arab states envisioned]]. Following the [[1948 Arab–Israeli war|conflict that ensued]], cease-fires and the [[1949 Armistice Agreements]] were negotiated and accepted by both sides. One of these resulted, in part, in a temporary division of Jerusalem. The relevant Armistice Agreement with Jordan was signed on April 3, 1949,{{cite web|url=http://avalon.law.yale.edu/20th_century/arm03.asp|title=The Avalon Project : Jordanian-Israeli General Armistice Agreement, April 3, 1949|website=avalon.law.yale.edu|accessdate=December 7, 2017}} but it was considered internationally as having no legal effect on the continued validity of the provisions of the partition resolution for the internationalization of Jerusalem.See "Corpus Separatum §33 Jerusalem" Marjorie M. Whiteman editor, US State Department ''Digest of International Law'', vol. 1 (Washington, DC: U. S. Government Printing Office, 1963) pages 593-4;''Foreign relations of the United States, 1948. The Near East, South Asia, and Africa'' (in two parts) Volume V, Part 2, Page 748; "Governing Jerusalem: Again on the world's agenda", by [[Ira Sharkansky]], Wayne State University Press, 1996, {{ISBN|0-8143-2592-0}}, page 23; and John Quigley, "The Legal Status Of Jerusalem Under International Law, The Turkish Yearbook Of International Relations, [VOL. XXIV, 1994] pp 11-25 On April 25, 1949, [[Abdullah I of Jordan|King Abdullah]] officially changed the name of Transjordan to the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan. He had secured the support of Great Britain (albeit qualified—Great Britain did not recognize the incorporation of East Jerusalem, maintaining that it ought to be part of a corpus separatum, an international enclave).[http://www.jcpa.org/jcpa/art/knesset6.htm THE CONSTITUENT ASSEMBLY: FIRST KNESSET 1949-1951. Annexation of the West Bank by the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607182941/http://www.jcpa.org/jcpa/art/knesset6.htm |date=June 7, 2011 }} On December 5, 1949 the Israeli Cabinet, meeting in [[Tel Aviv]], declared Jerusalem the capital of Israel, and on January 23, 1950, the [[First Knesset]] proclaimed that "Jerusalem was, and had always been, the capital of Israel."Martin Gilbert, ''Jerusalem in the Twentieth Century'' (New York, 1996), pp. 243-244. Moreover, on April 24, 1950, the Jordan House of Deputies and House of Notables, in a joint session, adopted a resolution annexing the West Bank and Jerusalem. Because the status of Jerusalem had been included previously in the UN Partition Plan, most countries did not accept this Israeli position, and most embassies have been located elsewhere.{{cite web|url=http://www.mfa.gov.il/MFA/Foreign+Relations/Israels+Foreign+Relations+since+1947/1947-1974/10+Jordanian+Annexation+of+West+Bank-+Resolution+A.htm|title=Jordanian Annexation of West Bank- Resolution Adopted by the House of Deputies, 24 April, 1950|website=Mfa.gov.il|accessdate=December 7, 2017}} The United States has stated that its policy on Jerusalem refers specifically to the geographic boundaries of the area that were set out for the "City of Jerusalem", or Corpus Separatum, in Resolution 181, but since 1950, US diplomats have traveled regularly to Jerusalem from the US Embassy in Tel Aviv to conduct business with Israeli officials.Gilbert, p. 253. The United States has also stated that Jerusalem was part of Mandate Palestine, and in a de jure sense, has not since become part of any other sovereignty.Foreign Relations of the United States, 1961-1963: Near East, 1962-1963, V. XVIII. DC: GPO, 2000, 152. Memorandum of conversation, February 7, 1963. Crawford (NE)-Campbell (IO)-Bar-Haim (Israeli Embassy) meeting: U.S. position on the status of Jerusalem {{Verify source|date=January 2017}}After the capture of the entire city and the adjacent West Bank in the 1967 [[Six-Day War]], the United States again reaffirmed the desirability of establishing an international regime for the city of Jerusalem.{{cite web|url=https://unispal.un.org/UNISPAL.NSF/0/510EF41FAC855100052566CD00750CA4|title=See General Assembly, A/L.523/Rev.1, 4 July 1967|website=Unispal.un.org|accessdate=December 7, 2017}} Advocacy for the Jerusalem Embassy Act reached a zenith during particularly critical times in negotiations for the [[Oslo Accords]] of the [[Israeli–Palestinian peace process|peace process]], despite opposition from both the Israeli and American administrations.[[Daniel Levy (political analyst)|Daniel Levy]], [http://www.prospect.org/cs/articles?articleId=11647 Is it Good for the Jews?] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20070810193628/http://www.prospect.org/cs/articles?articleId=11647 |date=August 10, 2007 }}, ''[[The American Prospect]]'', June 2006 The embassy move was, and continued to be, delayed by successive United States government in order to appear neutral on the issue of Jerusalem. However, on December 6, 2017, President [[Donald Trump]] announced that the US recognizes Jerusalem as the capital of Israel, and instructed the State Department to begin preparations to move the embassy.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-42259443|title=Jerusalem is Israel's capital - Trump|date=December 6, 2017|accessdate=December 7, 2017|website=Bbc.co.uk}} There are allegations by a group of Palestinians that the site is owned by Palestinian Refugees whose property was confiscated by Israel in 1948.{{cite journal|last=Khalidi|first=Walid|authorlink1=Walid Khalidi|title=The Ownership of the U.S. Embassy Site in Jerusalem|journal=[[Journal of Palestine Studies]]|date=2000|volume=29|issue=4|pages=80–101|doi=10.2307/2676563|JSTOR=2676563|publisher=[[University of California Press]]}} ==Details== The Act asserted that every country has a right to designate the [[Capital (political)|capital]] of its choice, and that Israel has designated Jerusalem. The act notes that "the city of Jerusalem is the seat of Israel's President, Parliament, and Supreme Court, and the site of numerous government ministries and social and cultural institutions." Jerusalem is defined as the spiritual center of [[Judaism]]. Furthermore, it stipulates that since the [[reunification of Jerusalem]] in 1967, religious freedom has been guaranteed to all. S.3(a)(2) and (3) also stated that ''"[[Jerusalem]] should be recognized as the capital of the State of [[Israel]]; and the United States Embassy in Israel should be established in Jerusalem no later than May 31, 1999"''. Although the Senate and House votes preceded visits by then Israeli Prime Minister [[Yitzhak Rabin]] and Jerusalem Mayor [[Ehud Olmert]] to [[Washington, D.C.|Washington]] to celebrate the 3000th anniversary of [[King David]]'s declaration of Jerusalem as the capital of the Jews,{{citation | url = http://www.jewishsf.com/content/2-0-/module/displaystory/story_id/2261/edition_id/37/format/html/displaystory.html | title = Jewish SF}}. little to no progress was achieved in the physical relocation of the U.S. Embassy to Jerusalem until December 2017. {{hatnote|Full text of the '''[[s:Jerusalem Embassy Act of 1995|Jerusalem Embassy Act of 1995 available on WikiSource]]'''}} ===Timetable=== Section 3 of the Act outlined the U.S. policy and set the initial parameters for the Secretary of State to report in order to receive the full funding — again, with a May 1999 target deadline for the appropriations. The section also briefly stated U.S. policy concerning the matter. {{quote| {{sm|Sec. 3. Timetable}}. : (a) {{sm|Statement of the Policy of the United States}}.— ::: (1) Jerusalem should remain an undivided city in which the rights of every ethnic and religious group are protected. ::: (2) Jerusalem should be recognized as the capital of the State of Israel; and ::: (3) the United States Embassy in Israel should be established in Jerusalem no later than May 31, 1999. : (b) {{sm|Opening Determination}}.— :: Not more than 50 percent of the funds appropriated to the Department of State for fiscal year 1999 for "Acquisition and Maintenance of Buildings Abroad" may be obligated until the Secretary of State determines and reports to Congress that the United States Embassy In Jerusalem has officially opened.}} The major roadblock has been the question of what effect, if any, the relocation may symbolize for other interested parties or neighboring nations involved in the ongoing and sometimes quite contentious Mid-East diplomacy and foreign relations. For this reason, since the legislation's introduction, the consensus has been that this action poses considerable risk to United States national security at home and abroad. ===Constitutional separation of powers=== Under the Constitution of the United States the President has exclusive authority to recognize foreign sovereignty over territory.See Restatement (3rd) Foreign Relations Law of the United States, American Law Institute, 1986, §§ 203 Recognition or Acceptance of Governments and §§ 204 Recognition and Maintaining Diplomatic Relations Law of the United States. The Justice Department's Office of Legal Counsel concluded that the provisions of the Embassy Relocation Act "invade exclusive presidential authorities in the field of foreign affairs and are unconstitutional."{{cite web |url=http://www.justice.gov/olc/s770.16.htm |title=Bill to Relocate United States Embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem: Memorandum Opinion for the Counsel to the President |publisher=United States Department of Justice |date=May 16, 1995 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100209074518/http://www.justice.gov/olc/s770.16.htm |archivedate=February 9, 2010}} Former U.S. presidents [[Bill Clinton]], [[George W. Bush]] and [[Barack Obama]] have alluded to or explicitly stated the belief that Congressional resolutions attempting to legislate foreign policy infringe upon the Executive's authority and responsibility to carry out sound and effective U.S. foreign relations. Regarding the status of Jerusalem specifically, President Bush had deemed Congress' role as merely "advisory", stating that it "impermissibly interferes with the President's constitutional authority".[https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2002/09/print/20020930-8.html Signing Statement by the President on H.R. 1646], the Foreign Relations Authorization Act, FY 2003, September 30, 2002, [[NARA]] Archives. The [[U.S. Constitution]] reserves the conduct of foreign policy to the President; resolutions of Congress, such as the ones found in the Authorization Act of 2003 that included the Jerusalem Embassy Act's provisions, makes the arguments in favor of legislating foreign policy from Congress extremely problematic if not arguably invalid for that Constitutional reason. Even from the Embassy Act's legislative beginnings, the question of Congress' over-reach, and whether it somehow usurped the Executive's authority or power over matters of foreign affairs, had played a subtle role in shaping the debate at the time. President Clinton took the unusual step of not signing the Embassy Act into law once Congress presented it to him, but instead, to show his disapproval, let 10 days of inaction pass, allowing the bill to return to Congress and automatically become law by Constitutional "default". Clinton's non-action reinforced this sticking point between the branches of the Federal government, without the potential public fallout from taking a "negative stand" on what appeared to be favorable, veto-proof legislation on the surface at the time.[http://clinton6.nara.gov/1995/10/1995-10-24-press-briefing-by-mike-mccurry.html Press Secretary Briefing, October 24, 1995], White House, National Archives and Records Administration.[https://www.archives.gov/exhibits/charters/constitution_transcript.html#1.7 Article I, Section 7, of the Constitution of the United States].Congressional Record, [http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d104:SN01322:@@@R Notes & Major Actions on the Embassy Act], S. 1322, [[104th Congress]], [[Office of the Federal Register|OFR]] [[Archivist of the United States]]. ===Presidential waiver=== This constitutional question was apparent while the legislation was working its way through both chambers; Sen. Dole's amendment adopted into the introduced language included a provision that, in part, returned to the Executive Branch the power over foreign affairs that it already had.
{{sm|Sec. 7. Presidential Waiver}}. : (a) {{sm|Waiver Authority}}.— ::: (1) Beginning on October 1, 1998, the President may suspend the limitations set forth in section 3(b) for a period of six months if he determines and reports to Congress in advance that such suspension is necessary to protect the national security interests of the United States. ::: (2) The President may suspend such limitations for an additional six-month period at the end of any period during which the suspension is in effect under this subsections if the President determines and reports to Congress in advance of the additional suspension that the additional suspension is necessary to protect the national security interests of the United States. ::: (3) A report under paragraph (1) or (2) shall include— ::::: (A) a statement of the interests affected by the limitation that the President seeks to suspend; and ::::: (B) a discussion of the manner in which the limitation affects the interests. : (b) {{sm|Applicability of Waiver to Availability of Funds}}.— :: If the President exercises the authority set forth in subsection (a) in a fiscal year for the purpose set forth in such section 3(b) except to the extent that the limitation is suspended in such following fiscal year by reason of the exercise of the authority in subsection (a).
Every six months since 1998, all presidents have invoked the waiver provision under section 7 of the Act, based on national security grounds, to defer the relocation of the embassy from Tel Aviv. The last waiver was signed by President Trump on June 4, 2018.https://s3.amazonaws.com/public-inspection.federalregister.gov/2018-14487.pdf Since this provision went into effect in late 1998, all the presidents serving in office during this period have determined moving forward with the relocation would be detrimental to U.S. national security concerns and opted to issue waivers suspending any action on this front. However, a re-assessment has to take place every six months. In response, members of Congress have begun to include language to do away with the President's exclusivity in making the determinations or flat-out remove the waiver provision completely from the Embassy Act altogether.{{cite web |url=http://www.govtrack.us/congress/billtext.xpd?bill=s111-2737&version=is&nid=t0%3Ais%3A31 |title=Jerusalem Embassy Relocation Act of 2009 |accessdate=December 7, 2009 |author=111th Congress (2009) |date=November 5, 2009 |work=S. 2737 |publisher=GovTrack.us |quote=}}{{cite web |url=http://www.govtrack.us/congress/billtext.xpd?bill=h111-3412&version=ih&nid=t0%3Aih%3A23 |title=Jerusalem Embassy and Recognition Act of 2009 |accessdate=December 7, 2009 |author=111th Congress (2009) |date=July 30, 2009 |work=H.R. 3412 |publisher=GovTrack.us |quote=}} {{hatnote|Full text of the '''[[s:Jerusalem Embassy Act of 1995|Jerusalem Embassy Act of 1995 available on WikiSource]]'''}} ==Developments== Noteworthy developments since the passage of the Act and well past the initial May 31, 1999 deadline's expiration: * Of the 22 Presidential Determinations to suspend the limitations that were issued between 1998 and the fall of 2009, only the Bush era issuances included the wording: {{quote|[The current] Administration remains committed to beginning the process of moving our embassy to Jerusalem;[[s:Jerusalem Embassy Act of 1995#Legislative History|Compiled List of Presidential Determinations]], Addendum to Public Law 104–45, Office of the Federal Register (FR pp compilation)}} : ... while President Obama's issuances mirror the wording first used by President Clinton. * Section 214 of the Foreign Relations Authorization Act, FY 2003 states: {{quote|The Congress maintains its commitment to relocating the United States Embassy in Israel to Jerusalem and urges the President ... to immediately begin the process of relocating the United States Embassy in Israel to Jerusalem.{{cite web |url=http://www.govtrack.us/congress/billtext.xpd?bill=h107-1646&version=enr&nid=t0:enr:449 |title=§ 214. Foreign Relations Authorization Act, FY 2003 |author=107th Congress (2001) |date=Apr 27, 2001 |work=H.R. 1646 |publisher=GovTrack | location = USA |quote=}}}} :The U.S. Congress, however, has the "[[power of the purse]]", and could prohibit the expenditure of funds on any embassy located outside Jerusalem. The U.S. Congress has not managed to repeat the incorporation or passage of language similar to that in Section 214, needed for any attempt to force a foreign policy change by withholding funding.{{cite web |url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Jerusalem%20gambit:%20how%20we%20should%20treat%20Jerusalem%20is%20a%20matter%20of%20U.S....-a017443652 |title=Jerusalem Gambit: How We Should Treat Jerusalem Is a Matter of U.S. Constitutional Law as Well as Middle Eastern Politics |accessdate=December 7, 2009 |author=Marshall J. Breger |date=October 23, 1995 |work=National Review |publisher=Gale |quote=But in the end, using the spending power to curtail the President's Article II authority won't work. Congress cannot use the power of the purse to seize a power textually committed to the Executive alone. While Congress can probably appropriate money for the construction of a building in West Jerusalem (and create a financial penalty if no construction takes place) it cannot use the "spending power" to order the Executive either in 1996 or 1999 to make that building an embassy rather than a consulate or cultural center. Nor can it order the President to recognize Israeli sovereignty over Jerusalem.}} Unsuccessful bills introduced to take certain steps toward the recognition by the U.S. of Jerusalem as the capital of Israel: *{{citation | quote = | volume = 1. United States Policy Regarding Jerusalem as the Capital of Israel |url=http://www.govtrack.us/congress/billtext.xpd?bill=h110-895&version=ih&nid=t0:ih:7 |title=H.R. 895 |accessdate=December 7, 2009 |work=Legislation |publisher=GovTrack | location = USA |quote=}} * Claims have arisen that as a result of the Embassy Act, official U.S. documents and web sites refer to Jerusalem as the capital of Israel, although this has been the case in many instances before the Act became law. The [[The World Factbook|CIA World Factbook]] has carried the typical Federal citation concerning Israel's capital and the absence of the usual concentration of foreign embassies being within its boundaries or proximity.{{citation | url = https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/is.html |chapter= Israel → Government → Capital | publisher = Central Ingelligence Agency | place = USA | year = 2011 |title= World FactBook}}. * A potential site for a future US Embassy office building in Jerusalem has been demarcated by Israel and the US, and is maintained in the neighborhood of [[Talpiot]]. Currently, the United States has three diplomatic office facilities in Jerusalem: [[Consulate General of the United States, Jerusalem|a consulate on Agron Road in West Jerusalem]], a consular annex on [[Nablus Road]] in East Jerusalem, and a new office annex in the neighborhood of [[Arnona]], located in an area of "[[no man's land]]" between East and West Jerusalem, which opened in October 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.israeltoday.co.il/NewsItem/tabid/178/nid/21990/Default.aspx|title=New US consulate to open in Jerusalem, but where's the embassy?|website=Israeltoday.co.il|accessdate=December 7, 2017}} In March 2011 a new bill, the Jerusalem Embassy and Recognition Act of 2011 ([[United States House of Representatives|H.R.]] [http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=h112-1006 1006]), was introduced. Cosponsored by fourteen [[United States Congress|Members of Congress]], including [[United States House Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on Europe and Eurasia|House Europe Subcommittee]] Chairman [[Dan Burton]] (R), [[United States House Committee on Foreign Affairs|House Foreign Affairs Committee]] Chairwoman [[Ileana Ros-Lehtinen]] (R) and [[United States House Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on the Middle East and South Asia|House Middle East Subcommittee]] Chairman [[Steve Chabot]] (R), the bill would discontinue the Presidential waiver authority included in the 1995 Act, relocate the [[List of diplomatic missions of the United States|U.S. Embassy in Tel Aviv]] to Jerusalem, and affirm the city as the undivided capital of Israel.{{cite news|last=Diament|first=Nathan|title=OU Commends Introduction of 2011 Jerusalem Embassy Act| url= http://www.ou.org/public_affairs/article/84044|accessdate= March 22, 2011| publisher = OU Institute for Public Affairs|date=March 22, 2011}} This bill died at the end of 2011, having failed to clear the [[United States House Committee on Foreign Affairs|House Foreign Affairs Committee]]. ===Under President Trump=== [[File:UN Resolution A ES-10 L.22.png|thumb|Countries votes about UN Resolution A/ES-10/L.22 (disapproval about US embassy moving in Jerusalem) in December 21, 2017.{{it}} [http://www.today.it/mondo/gerusalemme-capitale-onu.html ''Today.it'' - Gerusalemme Capitale, l'Onu condanna gli Usa: 128 Stati votano contro Trump]

{{legend|#0000FF|Favorable}} {{legend|#FF0000|Against}} {{legend|#00FF00|Abstained}} {{legend|#FF7F27|Not voted}}]] President [[Donald Trump]] signed the embassy waiver on June 1, 2017. The [[White House]] meanwhile stated that it did not represent a weakening of his support for Israel. It added that he stood by his promise of moving the embassy. On June 5, 2017, the U.S. Senate unanimously passed a resolution commemorating the 50th anniversary of reunification of Jerusalem by 90-0. The resolution reaffirmed the Jerusalem Embassy Act and called upon the President and all United States officials to abide by its provisions. On December 6, 2017, President Trump officially [[United States recognition of Jerusalem as Israeli capital|recognized Jerusalem as the capital of Israel]], and ordered the [[United States Department of State|State Department]] to begin planning for the relocation of the U.S. Embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem. However, following the announcement, Trump signed an embassy waiver again, delaying the move, as mandated by the Act, by at least six months.{{cite web|title=After Jerusalem recognition, Trump signs waiver delaying embassy move|date=December 7, 2017|author=Staff|publisher=The Times of Israel|accessdate=December 18, 2017|url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/after-jerusalem-recognition-trump-signs-waiver-delaying-embassy-move/}} [[United States Secretary of State|Secretary of State]] [[Rex Tillerson]] stated that the relocation process will begin immediately, but that the relocation itself however could take years to complete. Legally, however, the U.S. embassy can be moved at any time outside of the scope of the Act. On February 23, 2018, Trump announced that the US Embassy in Israel would reopen at the [[Arnona]] consular services site of the current US Consulate-General in Jerusalem on May 14, 2018, to coincide with the 70th anniversary of the [[Israeli Declaration of Independence]]. This announcement was welcomed by the [[Prime Minister of Israel|Israeli Prime Minister]] [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] and other Israeli government officials.{{cite news|last1=Hacohen|first1=Hagay|title=Israeli leaders embrace US decision to open Embassy in Jerusalem in May|url=http://www.jpost.com/Israel-News/Israeli-leaders-embrace-US-decision-to-open-embassy-in-Jerusalem-in-May-14-543474|accessdate=February 26, 2018|publisher=[[The Jerusalem Post]]|date=February 23, 2018}} However, the announcement was also condemned by Palestinian officials including [[Hanan Ashrawi]] and chief negotiator [[Saeb Erekat]] since the Embassy's reopening will coincide with the 70th anniversary of the [[1948 Palestinian exodus|"Nakba"]].{{cite news|last1=Tarnopolsky|first1=Noga|title=Date of U.S. Embassy move to Jerusalem shows how even the calendar is complicated in the Middle East|url=http://www.latimes.com/world/la-fg-israel-independence-day-20180224-story.html|accessdate=February 26, 2018|publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=February 24, 2018}} However, despite the move of the Embassy to Jerusalem, President Trump signed on June 4, 2018 an executive order postponing the move of the Embassy to Jerusalem, although it already moved to that city. He was required to sign the order since the Jerusalem Embassy Act requires the US Ambassador to have a permanent residence in Jerusalem, a condition not yet fulfilled.{{cite news |last1=Diamond |first1=Jeremy |title=Trump again signs embassy waiver despite move to Jerusalem |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/06/05/politics/trump-us-embassy-jerusalem/index.html |accessdate=October 21, 2018 |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=June 5, 2018}} On October 18, 2018, [[United States Secretary of State]] [[Mike Pompeo]] announced that the US Embassy and Consulate-General in Jerusalem would be merged into a single diplomatic mission. In addition, Pompeo announced the establishment of special Palestinian Affairs Unit inside the Embassy to conduct [[Palestine–United States relations|relations]] with the Palestinians.{{cite web |last1=Pompeo |first1=Mike |title=On the Merging of U.S. Embassy Jerusalem and U.S. Consulate General Jerusalem |url=https://jru.usconsulate.gov/on-the-merging-of-u-s-embassy-jerusalem-and-u-s-consulate-general-jerusalem/ |publisher=U.S. Consulate General in Jerusalem |accessdate=21 October 2018}} ===Public opinion=== A poll, taken in November 2017, by the [[Brookings Institution]] found that, of a national sample of 2,000 adults, 63% of Americans polled opposed the move of the embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem, while 31% supported it.{{cite news|url=https://www.brookings.edu/research/the-middle-east-and-russia-american-attitudes-on-trumps-foreign-policy/|title=The Middle East and Russia: American attitudes on Trump's foreign policy|author=Shibley Telhami|date=December 1, 2017|accessdate=January 22, 2017|agency=[[Brookings Institution]]}} Among Democrats, 81% opposed the move and 15% were in support, while among Republicans, 44% opposed the move and 49% supported it. In the 2017 AJC Survey of American Jewish Opinion, done in September 2017, it was found that 16% of American Jews polled supported an immediate move of the embassy to Jerusalem, 36% wanted to move the embassy at a later date in conjunction with Israeli-Palestinian peace talks, 44% opposed moving the embassy, and 4% said they weren't sure.{{cite news|url=https://www.ajc.org/survey2017|title=AJC Survey of American Jewish Opinion 2017|agency=AJC|date=September 13, 2017|accessdate=January 22, 2018}} ==See also== *[[Embassy of the United States, Jerusalem]] *[[Positions on Jerusalem]] *[[Jerusalem Day]] *[[Jerusalem Law]] *[[United Nations Security Council Resolution 478]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== ; Sample of Presidential Determination to suspend: :* Presidential Determination No. 99-29 — June 17, 1999, — {{USFR|64|33739}} - Clinton's first :* Presidential Determination No. 2001-19 — June 11, 2001 — {{USFR|66|34355}} - Bush's first :* Presidential Determination No. 2009-19 — June 5, 2009 — {{USFR|74|27903}} - Obama's first :* — [[s:Jerusalem Embassy Act of 1995#Legislative History|Compiled list of all PD's]] * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/3117182.stm Powell sued over Jerusalem's status], BBC News, published September 17, 2003. * [https://ecf.dcd.uscourts.gov/cgi-bin/show_public_doc?2003cv1921-53 Civil Action No. 2003-1921], (PDF), ''Zivotofsky et al. v. Secretary of State'', U.S. District Court, Judge Gladys Kessler, September 19, 2007 [[Category:1995 in American law]] [[Category:1995 in Israel]] [[Category:1995 in international relations]] [[Category:United States foreign relations legislation]] [[Category:Israel–United States relations]] [[Category:Diplomatic missions in Israel| ]] [[Category:20th century in Jerusalem]] [[Category:History of Tel Aviv]] [[Category:Israeli–Palestinian conflict in Jerusalem]] [[Category:International relations]] [[Category:Arab–Israeli conflict]]

{{Infobox person | name = Julio César Tello | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = April 11, 1880 | birth_place = [[Huarochirí Province]] | death_date = June 3, 1947 (aged 67) | death_place = [[Lima]] | death_cause = | residence = | other_names = | known_for = discovering early Peruvian cultures, such as Paracas and Chavín | education = [[Universidad Mayor de San Marcos|Universidad Nacional Mayor de San Marcos]]
[[Harvard University]] | employer = | occupation = | title = | salary = | networth = | height = | weight = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | religion = | spouse = Olive Chessman | partner = | children = | parents = | relatives = | signature = | website = | footnotes = | nationality = [[Peruvian]] }} '''Julio César Tello''' (April 11, 1880 – June 3, 1947) was a Peruvian [[Archaeology|archaeologist]].{{cite web |url= http://www.mnsu.edu/emuseum/information/biography/pqrst/tello_julio.html |title= Julio Cesar Tello |work= EMuseum, [[Minnesota State University, Mankato]] |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20060831071312/http://www.mnsu.edu/emuseum/information/biography/pqrst/tello_julio.html |archivedate= 2006-08-31 |df= }} Tello is considered the "father of Peruvian archeology" and was America's first [[indigenous people of the Americas|indigenous]] archaeologist. He made the major discoveries of the prehistoric [[Paracas culture]] and founded a national [[museum]] of archeology.[http://www.uiowapress.org/books/2009-spring/burger.htm Richard L. Burger, Abstract of "The Life and Writings of Julio C. Tello"], University of Iowa Press, accessed 27 September 2010 ==Biography== Tello was born a "mountain Indian" in an [[Andean]] village in [[Huarochirí Province]], Peru; his family spoke [[Quechua languages|Quechua]], the most widely spoken indigenous language in the nation. He was able to gain a first-class education by persuading the Peruvian government to fund it. Tello completed his [[Bachelor's degree]] in [[medicine]] at the [[National University of San Marcos]] in Peru in 1909. While still a student, Tello studied the practice of [[trepanation]] among natives of Huarochirí and amassed a very large collection of skulls. He was also studying early pathologies in the population. His collection became the basis for a collection at his university. His abilities were recognized early and senior men acted as mentors. He was awarded a scholarship by [[Harvard University]], where he learned English and earned his [[Master's degree]] in [[anthropology]] in 1911. Next he went to [[Europe]], where he studied [[archeology]]. In 1912 he attended the Congress of Americanists in [[England]], a group in which he became prominent in later years. It was the beginning of his active international life. Tello traveled widely during his career, and regularly invited other scholars to Peru, developing an international network. Although Tello published a number of papers in his lifetime, they appeared in little-known journals and newspapers, so they were not well known then even to Spanish speakers. For some time his findings and theories were not widely known outside of Peru because he did not publish in recognized academic journals. Tello discovered the cutler chain and paracas , that 2 cultures were one of the most old cultures in Peru.If you want to see more of this cutlers go to Peru.In peru you learn something new every day ! ==Marriage and family== In 1912 in England for a Congress of [[International Congress of Americanists|Americanists]], Tello met Olive Mabel Cheesman, an English woman who was a student at London University. They married that year and had several children together. Their eldest daughter died in December 1938. ==Career== In 1919 Tello was working with a team at the ''[[Chavín de Huantar]]'' [[archeological]] site, where he discovered a [[stele]] since named for him, the Tello [[Obelisk]]. Construction of the first temple at this major religious center was dated to 850 [[BCE]]. The work of Tello and others established that the site had been a center of complex culture that lasted for several hundred years, to sometime between 500 and 300 BCE. Until late-20th century discoveries established the dates of the 5000-year-old [[Norte Chico civilization|Norte Chico]] site, the [[Chavín culture]] was believed to be the oldest complex [[civilization]] in Peru. Tello is best known for his discovery in 1927 of 429 [[mummy]] bundles in the ''Cerro Colorado'' area of [[Peru]] on the [[Paracas Peninsula]]. He first visited the site on July 26, 1925, following a trail that had begun in 1915 when he had purchased ancient textiles in [[Pisco]]. On 25 October 1927, Tello and his team uncovered the first of hundreds of ceremonial mummified bundle burials. He was the first in Peru to practice a scientific method of archeological excavation, to preserve [[stratigraphy]] and elements to establish dating and context. In 1928 the team began to remove the mummies and textiles for safekeeping. His findings and interpretations have been the most significant source of information regarding the [[Paracas culture]], which dates to 750 BCE – 100 CE. The necropolis contained ritual burials, in which corpses were placed in baskets in a sitting position. Each of the bodies was covered by large textiles, works of woven cotton that had been [[embroidered]] in wool to create elaborate designs. He discovered these remarkable textiles which have been described as "spectacular".{{cite book|last=Feltham|first=Jane|title=Peruvian Textiles |pages= 46–7|year=1989|publisher=Shire Ethnography|isbn=0-7478-0014-6}} Tello and his team had collected 394 textiles and gained funding from the [[Rockefeller Foundation]] for their preservation. They put more than 180 on display by 1938 at the ''Instituto de Investigaciones Antropologicas'', where he and his team were on staff.{{cite book|last=Burger|first=Richard L.|title=The life and writings of Julio C. Tello: America's first indigenous archaeologist, pp. 1, 28 and 38-39, 72|year=2009|publisher=University of Iowa Press|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=75xVOiyWo4gC&pg=PA56&dq=paracas+tello+skulls&hl=en&ei=gLmhTNTHCNC6jAebtv2HAw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CDQQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=textiles&f=false}} Unlike some of his colleagues, Tello long believed that the [[Andean]] [[Highland (landform)|highlands]] had been important centers of ancient culture and made study of the area a focus of his work. His theory was proven by his work at sites such as [[Chavin de Huantar]] and [[Ayacucho]], a center of [[Wari culture]], as well as later scholars. In 1936 he, together with prominent scholars [[Alfred Kroeber]], [[Samuel Lothrop]], [[Wendell Bennett]] and others established the [[Institute for Andean Research]] (IAR), to organize and recognize contributions in the field. In 1938 the President, [[Óscar R. Benavides]], approved a reorganization of the national museums. Impressed with the Paracas textile collection, he authorized the new ''Museo de Antropolgia'' to house it. On January 3, 1939, Tello was named its first director. This is now the ''[[Museo Nacional de Arqueología, Antropología e Historia del Perú]]''. The [[Julio C Tello Museum]] on the Paracas Peninsula is named in his honour. After the reserve was established in 1975, the museum was built to house artifacts and interpret the archeology and culture of the Paracas, as well as the rich natural life of the marine reserve. ==Bibliography== * [[Alberto Tauro del Pino|Tauro del Pino, Alberto]]: ''Enciclopedia Ilustrada del Perú''. Tomo 16. TAB/UYU. Lima, PEISA, 2001. {{ISBN|9972-40-165-0}} * ''Grandes Forjadores del Perú''. Lima, Lexus Editores, 2000. {{ISBN|9972-625-50-8}} * [[Richard L. Burger|Burger, Richard]], ''The Life and Writings of Julio C. Tello.America's First Indigenous Archaeologist''. University of Iowa Press, 2010. ==Legacy and honors== * Considered the "father of Peruvian archeology". * Richard L. Burger, ''The Life and Writings of Julio C. Tello'', University of Iowa Press, 2009, makes his works and their significance available to a wider audience. * Julio C. Tello Museum, named in his honor and established to hold his findings of the Paracas culture. * Tello Obelisk, named in his honor, monument of the [[Chavín culture]]. ==See also== {{Commons category|Julio C. Tello}} *[[Paracas Textiles]] *[[Paracas culture]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tello, Julio C.}} [[Category:1880 births]] [[Category:1947 deaths]] [[Category:Harvard University alumni]] [[Category:Andean scholars]] [[Category:Peruvian archaeologists]] [[Category:Peruvian people of Quechua descent]] [[Category:National University of San Marcos alumni]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of the Sun of Peru]] [[Category:People from Lima Region]]

{{Eastern name order|Szalárdi János}} '''János Szalárdi''' (23 July 1601 – 27 September 1666) was a [[Hungary|Hungarian]] historian in the [[Principality of Transylvania (1570–1711)|Principality of Transylvania]].
He was appointed one of the conservators of the Transylvanian Archives in [[Alba Iulia|Gyulafehérvár]] (today: ''Alba Iulia, Romania''). He served as Secretary of the Chancellery (1644–1649) during the reign of [[George I Rákóczi]] when the position of [[Chancellor of Transylvania|Chancellor]] was vacant since 1634, the death of [[István Kovacsóczy]]. Later he was appointed Secretary for [[Prince of Transylvania]]. He participated in the [[Transylvanian Diet]] of 1666 which commissioned him to collection of taxes of the [[Partium]], [[Kolozs County|Kolozs]], [[Doboka County|Doboka]] and [[Szolnok-Doboka County|Inner Szolnok Counties]]. Szalárdi died in [[Făgăraș|Fogaras]] (today: ''Făgăraș, Romania'').
==Works== * ''The Nine Books of Chronicle Lamentations'' (edited after manuspricts by [[Zsigmond Kemény]] in [[Pest, Hungary|Pest]], 1853). Excellent reference work for the [[history of Transylvania]] after [[George II Rákóczi]]'s unfortunate campaign of 1657.
==Sources== * [http://mek.niif.hu/00300/00355/html/ABC14240/14432.htm Hungarian Biographical Lexikon]

The '''Kennedy Professorship of Latin''' is the senior [[List of Professorships at the University of Cambridge|professorship]] of [[Latin]] at the [[University of Cambridge]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.classics.cam.ac.uk/faculty/donations/ |title=Faculty of Classics |publisher=Classics.cam.ac.uk |accessdate=2009-11-20}}</ref>
In 1865, when [[Benjamin Hall Kennedy]] retired as headmaster of [[Shrewsbury School]], his friends and former pupils created a fund with the intention of founding a chair in Latin to be named after him. Kennedy himself added £500 to the fund on the condition that the chair ''not'' be named after him! The professorship was thus created in 1869. In 1911, after Kennedy's death, the professorship was in fact renamed after him, with the consent of his family.
==Munro Kennedy Professors== * [[Hugh Andrew Johnstone Munro]] (1869) * [[John Eyton Bickersteth Mayor]] (1872) * [[Alfred Edward Housman]] (1911) * [[William Blair Anderson]] (1936–1942) * [[Roger Mynors|Roger Aubrey Baskerville Mynors]] (1944) * [[Charles Oscar Brink]] (1954) * [[Edward John Kenney]] (1974–1982) * [[Michael David Reeve]] (1984-2006) * [[Stephen Oakley]] (2007-)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.emma.cam.ac.uk/about/fellows/display/?fellow=247 |title=Emmanuel College - The Fellows |publisher=Emmanuel College |accessdate=2009-11-20}}</ref>
